PETITION.TITLE: Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:

1. They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to reject the recommendations of the Commonwealth Schools Commission contained in 'Funding Policies for Australian Schools', concerning proposed increases in State aid for private schools and the proposed community standard for education funding.

2. They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to declare a three year moratorium (1985-1987) on increases in State aid to private schools and on grants for new private schools and for increased private school enrolments.

3. They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to re-affirm their primary obligation to government schools and to implement all 1983 ALP election promises for increased funding to government schools.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt,Mrs Darling,Mrs Kelly,Mr Kent,Mr Milton,Mr Scott and Mr Staples .

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully sheweth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia , namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation 's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that 'the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blanchard,Mr Blunt,Mr McArthur and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth; that Regulations and an Ordinance now before the Parliament amend the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations and the Customs ( Cinematographic Films) Regulations and supersede the A.C.T. Objectionable Publications Ordinance in such a manner as to be harmful to society by removing from existing Commonwealth law:
The power to prevent the importation and sale of hard-core pornography (e.g. X- rated videos) and publications which consistently incite the use of hard drugs;
the power to prevent the importation and sale of grossly obscene publications, including those associated with blasphemy;
the power to require imported video tapes/discs for non-commercial use to be registered by the Films Censorship Board.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled: should disallow the new Regulations and Ordinance and ensure:
That the Attorney-General enforce existing laws.
That Censors more appropriately reflect responsible community attitudes.

That further measures be taken in association with the States to protect Australians, particularly women and children, from exploitation; and that, because of the importance of this issue to society, a conscience vote be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blanchard,Mr Burr,Mr Groom and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Omega Base
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that . . .

1. Omega by sending low frequency signals, penetrating sea water enables hunter -killer submarines to establish their position and to launch a 'first strike' attack. Omega is also used by AWACs, the flying radar stations, and for other military purposes.
2. Omega is an important U.S. military base and a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Omega would have a disastrous effect on Victoria and Melbourne .
3. Omega and other U.S. bases in Australia endanger, rather than protect us. They add a new unnecessary menace to a nuclear arms race that must be stopped, if we are to survive.
Your petitioners pray the members and the House assembled will close Omega.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles and Mr Milton.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the overwhelming majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian National Flag.

2. That we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, unless such proposed change is first voted on by the people of Australia and passed by a majority of voters in a majority of States.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fife and Mr Macphee.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and its future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression:
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Dobie,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Ruddock and Mr Spender.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax: Confectionery
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that the current discriminatory application of sales tax on confectionery at the rate of 20% is an unfair and unjust burden on this important manufacturing industry and your petitioners therefore pray that confectionery be treated in a similar fashion to all other foods, including snack foods, which are exempt from sales tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Rocher and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that we believe that there are unresolved economic, social, biological, genetic, environmental, technical and ethical problems associated with the mining of Uranium and the Development of Nuclear power, in particular:
(a) to the proven contribution of the nuclear power industry to the proliferation of nuclear weapons and the increased risk of nuclear war; and
(b) the absence of procedures for the storage and disposal of radioactive wastes to ensure that any danger posed by such wastes to human life and the environment is eliminated.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that:
(1) No new Uranium mines be commenced;
(2) No new contracts for the sale of Uranium be approved;
(3) Uranium mines presently in production cease with the fulfilment of current contracts;
(4) No new Uranium is supplied to countries making or testing nuclear weapons.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Monitoring Medical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth-

That the current ''epidemic'' of adverse reactions to medical drugs (both prescription and over-the-counter) constitutes a severe health problem. The monitoring of such reactions is inadequate. There is a lack of awareness of the role of such drugs in causing disease. Consumers are confused by the large number of unnecessary brand names for the same drug. There is insufficient onus on drug companies to compensate the victims of adverse drug reactions.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray-
1. That there should be-
(a) Mandatory reporting of suspected drug reactions to the Adverse Drug Reactions Advisory Committee (A.D.R.A.C.).
(b) Recording of pre-death medication on death certificates.
(c) Collection and publication of the resulting statistics.
2. That the labelling of drugs should include-
(a) Generic (or chemical) names in place of brand names.
(b) Warnings of recorded adverse reactions.
3. That Australia should seek uniform international surveillance of medical drugs.
4. That pharmaceutical companies be made automatically liable for injury or death caused directly or indirectly by their products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Generic Drug Names
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth-
That there are far too many prescription drugs available and that abuse of these constitutes a serious problem.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray-
1. That all drugs shall be prescribed and supplied by their approved (Generic) names only. Trade (Brand) names will not be used in any circumstances.
2. That information concerning possible side-effects of all drugs must be made as freely available as the drugs themselves.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We assert that TAFE, with over 1 million students, requires greatly improved resources if it is to continue to train Australia's skilled workforce effectively.

2. We call upon the Commonwealth Government to provide greatly increased funds to ensure that TAFE is accessible to all Australians, unlike the present time when thousands of people are turned away from TAFE colleges each year.

3. We urge the Commonwealth Government to equip TAFE workshops with the advanced technology used in modern Australian industries, and to expand TAFE's capital works program so that sufficient quality accommodation is available for TAFE teachers and students.
4. We ask that the Commonwealth Government greatly increase TAFE's recurrent expenditure, so that TAFE can respond quickly and flexibly to industry, Government and community demands.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. The Federal Labor Government's retirement income policies are piecemeal, inconsistent and make no provision to encourage people to save towards their retirements; and
2. The Government's proposed assets test legislation is iniquitous and, if enacted, its effects would be discriminatory.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
1. scrap its proposed assets test legislation;
2. either institute a broad enquiry into Australia's retirement income and taxation systems or await the outcome of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare's work on this matter; and,
3. following the report of such a wide enquiry institute a retirement income policy which is fair and equitable, that encourages self-provision and which will be non-discriminatory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

That we are totally opposed to any legislation which allows video films, films, and books dealing with sex, drugs, crime, cruelty and revolting phenomena, to be imported, produced and dealt with commercially in Australia. For this is promoting evil, ''Satan and all his works.'' We, the undersigned request the Government to abandon its 1983 decision to alter the A.C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinance forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance

We the undersigned request the Government to abandon its 1983 decision to alter the A.C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinance forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:

That we object in the strongest possible way to the importation of all forms of pornography, and liberalising the use of hard drugs. These are, we feel, detrimental to all family units and are the cause of the destruction of our Society which we value extensively.

We implore that the Attorney-General and all other members of the present Government, treat this with utmost urgency and abandon the 1983 decision to alter the A.C.T. Classification of Publication Ordinance forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:

That we sincerely believe that the new Commonwealth censorship procedures for publication and the A.C.T. Classification Ordinance 1983 standards for classification of printed materials, No. 1-February 1984 passed by the Senate last Wednesday, removing from existing Commonwealth law;-
(a) The power to prevent the importation and sale of hardcore pornography (e.g. X-rated videos).
(b) The power to prevent the importation and sale of grossly obscene publications including those associated with blasphemy;
(c) The power to require videos for non-commercial use to be registered by the Films Censorship Board before release from customs
Was a step in the wrong direction.

It is the view of the religious community on the north side of Brisbane, of which we are a part, that the new laws should be amended immediately to give protection to all Australians, particularly women and children from exploitation .

It is believed that those materials that come under category 2 classification should not be allowed to be made available to all, and the knowledge that this kind of material described under classification 2 is now lawful under the new regulations is nauseating.

We respectfully request that amending legislation be drafted accordingly.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Committee on the Effects of Pornography on Children

We, the undersigned, plead that the House of Representatives will vote in favour of the Senate resolution calling for the appointment of a Select Joint Committee to examine the effects upon children of viewing pornographic, violent and obscene video material, because not all parents are supervising all children all of the time, and not all video outlets are impoverishing themselves by compliance with the law. PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government

PETITION.TITLE: Chiropractic Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows -
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractics provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioners of one's choice and does nothing to reduce the high cost of health care in Australia.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedom;
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action Hospitals, Doctors and Nurses, who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development, including moral development of their children.
Deny to parents their rights to have their children enjoy single-sex sporting activities e.g., boys cricket team, boys football team, etc.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Parliament assembled should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of all principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: General Motors-Holden's Ltd.
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: We the Citizens of the City of Woodville and supported by the citizens of South Australia, being deeply concerned over the threat of closure of the Woodville Plant of General Motors-Holdens, respectfully show-
1. That the management of General Motors-Holdens has failed over a period of more than two (2) years to give any assurances that the Woodville Plant would continue in operation.
2. That a recent statement attributed to the GMH Managing Director, quote:-
''The overall objective of our South Australian rationalisation plan has been to eliminate all productive activities on the Woodville site'' end of quote.
This statement has not been refuted.
3. That the elimination of the Woodville Plant will cause enormous social dislocation, hardship and misery to the citizens of Woodville and South Australia.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament of Australia will condemn this callous disregard for the citizens of Woodville and South Australia, and do all in its power to force General Motors-Holdens to retain its operations at the Woodville Plant.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL REFORM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, I present the second report of the Committee, together with the minutes of the proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The second report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform deals primarily with political advertising. The Committee's first report, which I presented to this House in September 1983, contains about 200 recommendations for reform of the Australian electoral system. Most of those recommendations were adopted by the Government and by the Parliament and were included in the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Act 1983. That report also foreshadowed the further inquiry by the Committee into standards governing political advertising and provisions governing the broadcast of political material.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of this inquiry the Committee became aware of the broad nature of the prohibition of untrue and misleading political advertising brought about by amendments made to the then section 161(2) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, which, by the way, were not recommended by this Committee. After much consideration the Committee has concluded that this section could seriously disrupt the orderly process of political campaigning and has recommended the repeal of the section. I urge the Government to effect this repeal before the next general election.

The Committee has also recommended on a number of other points. One is a simplification of the provisions of the Broadcasting and Television Act concerning the identification of political advertisements. We recommend the removal of these provisions from the Electoral Act and their transfer to the Commonwealth Broadcasting and Television Act. We feel that in the case of a registered political party the broadcast of the name of the party should be sufficient. We also recommend that the Australian Electoral Commission publish a manual of Australian electoral law and practice, including relevant obligations not contained in the Commonwealth Electoral Act but contained in other Commonwealth Acts.

We also recommend that the identification requirements of the Broadcasting and Television Act apply only to advertising so as to exclude talk-back radio and man-in-street interviews. We also recommend that the ban on the dramatisation of political material be repealed. We recommend that the Broadcasting and Television Act be amended to provide that a person shall be afforded the opportunity to examine any record and to obtain a copy of such record upon notice and upon payment of such costs as are reasonable to cover the expenses of the broadcast and of providing a copy tape, rather than the present position where proceedings actually have to be initiated before such copies are provided. We also recommend similar provisions for television. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, I present the report of the Committee entitled 'Protection of the Greater Daintree', incorporating a dissenting report, together with extracts of the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report which has just been tabled is the Committee's first report for the thirty-third Parliament and the twenty-third since the Committee was established in 1973. The Committee decided to report without formal inquiry because of the sensitivity of the issue and its belief that there was a need for some preliminary comments. Members inspected the area in June and were appalled to see what was happening. Even though there is a dissent to this report, I think all honourable members would agree that the location of the road and the manner in which it is being constructed is a matter of concern.

SPEECH.PARA: The report makes no comments as to whether or not the region is of World Heritage status but rather acknowledges the studies that are presently being undertaken, identifies areas where more study is required and suggests appropriate consultative procedures which should be entered into by the Commonwealth Government, the Queensland Government and the Douglas Shire Council . The Committee notes that some approaches have been made by the Commonwealth to Queensland concerning the road. It is apparent that these discussions have been unsuccessful as construction of the road continues. The report concludes that the Commonwealth may not have exhausted all consultative mechanisms. We believe that, given statements by the Queensland Premier concerning the outstanding value of the area, further approaches and offers of assistance by the Commonwealth may result in a change of attitude and lead to a more environmentally appropriate approach to the area.

We have recommended that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) make further approaches to the Queensland Government to seek agreement on the cessation of further damaging activities pending the results of the present study of rainforests in north Queensland. We have asked that the Government complete its assessment of World Heritage status as a matter of urgency and, should it be found that it is of World Heritage status, the Commonwealth, in consultation with the Queensland Government, proceed with nomination of the area as soon as possible.

The report notes that not everyone is convinced that the road will seriously degrade the national and international values of the region. We have recommended that the Commonwealth Government commission a scientific study to determine the impact of the road on the region's heritage values. We have noted that while the region's World Heritage value is yet to be established, it is generally recognised as having special values in terms of Australia's heritage. Regardless of the outcome of the World Heritage evaluation, the Committee considers that special consideration should be given by the Commonwealth to provide funding and other assistance, including funding for an alternative road, and we have recommended accordingly.

We recognise the studies recommended by the Committee and that the assessments now under way may take some time to complete. We feel that it is appropriate that if, in the short term, the Queensland Government and Douglas Shire have been asked to defer current planning proposals, this places and obligation on the Commonwealth to accept some responsibility for providing funding regardless of the outcome of these assessments. The Committee briefly examined the Commonwealth's legislative powers. It appears that both the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act and the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act may apply. Apart from the difficulties in establishing that pollution from the road may harm the reef, the Committee considers that there are other good reasons for not applying this Act. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act is meant for and is achieving sound management of the Marine Park.

It is our belief that it would not be appropriate to use the Act to prevent further construction of the road as this could irreparably damage the delicate arrangement which exists between the Commonwealth and Queensland governments concerning sound management of what effectively represents 80 per cent of the eastern Queensland coast. The Committee noted the comments of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment relating to the application of the World Heritage Act. The Minister said:

A unilateral decision by Australia before proper assessment has been made or before a proposal has been submitted to the World Heritage Committee could lead to the debasing of the World Heritage List.

A precedent could be established which may lead to pressure for the Act to be used whenever conservationists are in disagreement with State governments. The majority of members of the Committee believes that the Act should not be used for general conservation purposes and should be invoked only when a listed place or places under consideration for listing are under threat.

The Committee concludes that if, and only if, all the consultative approaches and offers of assistance, which I have mentioned previously, fail, the Commonwealth Government should consider applying the provisions of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act. We hope that such action will not be necessary as we find it difficult to believe that the Queensland Government and the Douglas Shire Council would reject an approach by the Commonwealth involving proper consultation and offers of financial and other assistance.

While the issue of the road is important, we must not lose sight of the wider issue here, which is proper management of the region as a whole. We hope that, if the recommendations of the Committee are accepted by the Commonwealth and agreement can be reached with Queensland, a series of events will be set in train which will ensure the preservation of the region for future generations of Australians. I commend the report to the House.

In other words, one can anticipate that that report will contain significant information which should have been available to this parliamentary committee prior to its reporting to the Parliament. Nevertheless, the decision was taken by a majority of members of the Committee that the report should be put forward to the Parliament without access to what I am sure will be a very significant report. As I said earlier, it is because of that attitude that members of the Opposition believed it was not possible for us to support the report in toto, despite the fact that we are sympathetic with the need to do our best at the Commonwealth level to ensure the long term protection, in particular, of the tropical rainforests in the Daintree area.

I turn to specific aspects of the report. We strongly disagree with those sections which suggest that the Commonwealth pursue action which will result in World Heritage nomination, irrespective of the views of, and the need to reach agreement with, the Queensland Government. In fact, it is fair to say that the recommendation in the report on that subject can best be defined as confrontationist. Keeping in mind the fact that environmental matters have traditionally been the responsibility of State governments, we therefore conclude that this approach is shortsighted and has serious implications for the management of all areas around Australia which may well be of significance, either nationally or internationally, and which will yet again frighten off State governments-Liberal , Labor and National Party alike-which will see this as but another demonstration of the intention of the Federal Labor Government to force its will upon State governments in these matters. We recognise that the Commonwealth should play an active role in assisting States in the management of areas considered by the States and the Commonwealth to be of major national conservation significance. In that context, of course, we include the Daintree rainforest. But the basis of that must be one of co-operation and consultation, and not one based on threats and pretence by the Commonwealth that it will assert itself in these areas of traditional State responsibility.

We believe that the recommendation contained in paragraph 55, which threatens the application of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act against Queensland, is therefore unnecessary and inconsistent with the main thrust of the report, which we support, which is the need to encourage the Federal Government to take all steps necessary and possible to enter into further substantive negotiations with Queensland and the Douglas Shire Council to see what can be done to achieve a long term settlement and to put in place a long term regime for the protection of the Daintree national park area. But we cannot achieve that without the obvious support of the Queensland Government. To travel down the other road is to enter into constant confrontation, for which members of the Government are well aware that they will have to pay a very heavy political price.

Notwithstanding our comments relating to the preparation and contents of the report, we do not-and I emphasise this point-oppose nomination of the Daintree area for the World Heritage List if it is so determined to be of such significance. Again, the nomination for the World Heritage List should be proposed with the support of the Queensland Government. We are, and have been for some months, most concerned that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment did not, as I said earlier, offer assistance prior to the road's commencement in November 1983. We believe that a lack of a positive co-operative approach by the Minister and the Government has contributed to the present unsatisfactory situation and needless confrontation.

Anyone who studies the views of the Minister since last year will see quite clearly that the Government at a very early stage-in fact, as early as 30 November 1983 and since 17 August this year-has been consistent on one point; that is, it has absolutely refused to offer funds to Queensland for the long term protection of this area, for the funding of alternative roads or for any other level of substantive Federal intervention or involvement. SPEECH.PARA: In speaking about the report, I preface my remarks by referring to this statement by the Premier of Queensland:
The greater Daintree area provides a living museum of plant and animal species in what is one of the few remaining examples of undisturbed coastal rainforest in the world.

Those were the words of the Premier of Queensland on 13 June 1980. There are probably not many areas of life, or comments, on which I would be in agreement with the Premier of Queensland. But on the issue of the unique beauty and environmental rarity of the magnificent rainforest area of Daintree, I am in 100 per cent agreement. It is indeed a living museum of plant and animal species and is one of the few remaining examples of undisturbed coastal rainforest in the world. Perhaps the Premier has forgotten his words of 1980. Those words hardly rest comfortably with the actions of the Queensland Government in urging the Douglas Shire Council to work quickly on the construction of the road to Bloomfield.

I am honoured to be a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation which recently visited the Cape Tribulation and Daintree area. I feel privileged to be numbered amongst the minority of Australians who have actually been to this magnificent area and seen at first hand its beauty and wonder. I would like to share with the House and those members of the Australian community listening to this debate some of my impressions and observations of this area. The forests of the Daintree region include the largest stand remaining on the mainland of Australia. They also represent the last stands of lowland rainforest which are distinct from the more common forms that are left behind by greedy developers.

These are the wet diverse forests. The climate is warm and humidity is high due to both the geographical position and the high mountains of the Great Dividing Range which run down to the sea. For about three months of the year in the wet season almost unrelieved downpours provide an enforced holiday for both human and non-human residents. At Mount Sorrow, behind Cape Tribulation, species of dragonfly, water beetle and water bug live out their complete life cycles in leaf litter, away from the streams and ponds required by the rest of their insect relatives. This phenomenon is certainly unique in Australia and probably in the rest of the world.

The white soft sandy beaches are lined by pandanus palms, cottonwood hibiscus and the coast she-oak. Closely hugging the shoreline is a fringing coral reef. Can honourable members imagine the immense beauty of the deep green of the tropical rainforest running down to the golden and white sands of the beaches which are gently lapped by the deep aquas and turquoise of the coral sea? Its beauty is astounding. The fringing coral reef that is so close to the shoreline has already been recognised as extremely important by its classification under category B of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act. This is one of the few intact reefs bordering the mainland shore and it is this magnificent reef that is at danger by silting from the road as the mud is washed to the water in the wet season.

In the depths of the rainforest there is little, if any, understorey except where a fallen tree, a storm or a wide stream has cut across the canopy. It is like a vast magnificent hall with a soft spongy floor of leaf mould separated by great pillar-like tree trunks from the multi-layered canopy. It can be likened to a huge magnificent cathedral, an example of nature's gift to us to behold. It is in this intricate garden of leaves, fruiting and flowering trees and vines that most of the forest birds can be found. Up to 150 tree species can be found on a couple of hectares, many more than in Europe or North America. At least seven species of vertebrate animal have been found nowhere else in the world- four new species of frogs, the Bennets tree kangaroo and a so far undescribed species of skink. A newly discovered ringtail possum will certainly be added to this list.

Only now are we beginning to appreciate the richness of the area. Eleven distinct types of rainforest have been identified in the Daintree area. Daintree has some of the last coastal rainforest in Australia. It is about the last stretch of coast that remains as Captain Cook saw it in 1770. When we think about all this it is hard to understand why the road is going ahead. Many people have endeavoured to stop the road and its destruction of this most beautiful and magnificent area. They have been set upon by dogs and fined $1,200 for trying to protect the forest. I commend all those people and thank them for their stand. Future generations will look upon this environmental vandalism with disgust and dismay just as we are dismayed with the destruction caused by past generations on our exquisite planet.

I have been told that the road has already passed through the forest, that illegal size drainage has been put down under the road for expediency. What madness! Why the rush? Is it to open up more land for the lust and greed of wealth? The long term wealth of our nation relies on these magnificent areas. They must be kept for future generations. I can only plead on behalf of those who are to follow us that this area be protected. I reiterate the words of the Queensland Premier. He said:
The greater Daintree area provides a living museum of plant and animal species in what is one of the few remaining examples of undisturbed coastal rainforest in the world.
I commend the report to the House and the nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am grateful for the opportunity given to me today to speak to the report on the protection of the greater Daintree. Like the previous speakers to this report, I was fortunate to be able to go up to the greater Daintree in early July, to see at first hand the beauty of which the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Chynoweth) spoke. Certainly, from all reports the rainforests around the world are disappearing very quickly. In fact, hundreds of acres a day are disappearing. While we were there we were able to witness for ourselves, in the Cow Bay area, some of that destruction where subdividers have subdivided one section of the rainforest. What an obscene development it was. We saw the roads pushed through the rainforest which was subdivided into blocks, as one would subdivide land in metropolitan areas for sale to people to build homes on. To see trees and an environment that have grown for millions of years pushed aside by bulldozers, I am sure made a deep impression on everybody who went up there.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to consider the values we hold as human beings towards the destruction of our environment. I venture to say that if we were to talk about pushing down such notable buildings as St Pauls in London or the Taj Mahal there would be a public outcry. I can remember that in Perth about 10 years ago when the State Government wanted to push down the Barracks Arch there was a great public outcry, and justifiably so. In some cases such buildings have been there for less than 100 years. If we were to attempt to push down this House, in which I stand today, I am sure a vocal group would try to stop us from doing so. Yet the rainforests in north Queensland have been growing for millions of years. I wonder about the values we place on things provided by nature and man. Certainly , I am sure the rest of the Committee would like to preserve the rainforests in north Queensland. I know the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) also holds that view, so the Opposition does not oppose the World Heritage listing. We are really talking about a political decision. Who makes the final decision on the Daintree? Do we leave it to the Queensland Government to look after that part of Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not?
—The honourable member opposite interjects and says: 'Why not?'
—It has done a good job.

—It has done a good job in the Cow Bay area where the local council was against the development. I ask the honourable member to look at what the Queensland Government has done and, in particular, Mr Hinze. He rode over the top of the wishes of the local council and allowed that development to go ahead. A sub-developer who does not even live in Australia was able to demolish trees and an environment that had survived for millions of years. That is the value that the Queensland Government places on that part of the environment. Certainly , I think it is the duty of the Australian Government, as the protector of the things that we value on a national basis, to take an interest in it. It comes back to a States rights argument. If we leave it to the Queensland Government I am sure, based on past experience, before we arrived at the consensus at which we would all wish to arrive, most of that forest would have disappeared and the environment would have been irreparably damaged.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Committee has brought down a very soft report. We have stressed that we want to co-operate with the Queensland Government if we can, but we do not hold back from the fact that if it wants, for its own reasons, to push roads into and develop that area, as it has in the Cow Bay area, we as a government have a responsibility to the Australian people to step in and use the World Heritage powers if we can. If those powers are available to us at the time, we should protect the environment.

I conclude by thanking the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Wells), who has gone out of his way to try to reach an amicable agreement between the Queensland Government, the local Douglas Shire Council and this Committee. He came to us yesterday and spoke of his efforts. Although the Daintree area is not within his electorate, I believe he, as a concerned member for Queensland in this Parliament, has performed an admirable task. I hope that the Queensland Government will co-operate with the Australian Government, but if it does not we should step in and use any power available to us to protect that part of the world because I think we owe it to future generations of Australians.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 August, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members know that it is not often they have an opportunity to comment on problems as they see them within and without their nation. It is not often that they have a chance to assess the Federal Government 's reaction and response to those problems, but each year in the Budget debate each member has a chance to comment on behalf of his or her own electorate on local problems and, with a wider or deeper overview, problems facing our nation. I believe the Budget brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) this week to be a responsible and very sensitive instrument, a very finely honed document, giving support where support is needed and giving help to those in our community who are the most needy.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Australian Labor Party was elected to government in March last year the economy was in severe decline, unemployment was rising at 11.5 per cent a year, inflation was rampant and the notorious Budget blow-out became evident once the government changed. In the last 12 months all expectations of a healthy return to a sound financial basis have been greatly exceeded. The Treasurer, in his Budget Speech, pointed out that 230,000 Australians have found jobs, compared with 240,000 who lost their jobs in the previous year. He also pointed out that inflation fell to 6.5 per cent and that at present it is running at an annual rate of 5 per cent. If inflation is falling it means that Australia now has the same level of inflation as our major trading partners. The Treasurer also pointed out that Australia has the fastest economic growth rate in the Western world and we have turned in the best performance in 25 years, with an annual economic growth rate of 10 per cent, which is a great credit to the Australian people and to the Government which brought this about.

Much praise for what is happening in our nation must go to the Australian trade union movement. The prices and incomes accord, which was attacked by the previous Liberal Government, has worked and this has meant that our nation has got out of its difficult position and has entered on a firm economic course to fight inflation and unemployment.

I want to touch briefly on some of the Government's economic policies and, in particular, the extra assistance given by the Budget to education. In the electorate of Lowe it would be a toss-up as to whether the state schools are more in need of aid than the non-state schools. I congratulate the Government for the package of aid it has given not only to government schools but also to the non-government sector, which educates about 50 per cent of the pupils in my electorate. The needs of Australian children are great, particularly in the older suburbs where the schools are run down, and where a large percentage of the pupils are from migrant families which might not speak English at home. The Government has also increased aid to tertiary education. There have been substantial funding increases for technical and further education colleges and additional places have been created at universities, colleges of advanced education and institutes of technical and further education.

The Budget also deals with the various departmental votes. I am pleased to note that increased funding is to go to the repatriation hospitals. The Concord Repatriation General Hospital is in the electorate of Lowe. The Government has done great things for this hospital. It is building a new operating block and I am pleased to say that it is also looking at a proposal to upgrade ward accommodation. It is essential in this day and age to do away with the large, all-in wards. People now have a higher expectation of ward accommodation in hospitals. They require more single rooms, and these are essential, particularly for terminal cases and for people who are very ill. The Concord Hospital serves not only the veterans in New South Wales but also the local community. About 20 per cent of the patients at the hospital are local people. I praise the work of the medical and nursing staff, the administrators and the domestic staff at this important hospital.

Another area in the Budget I want to touch on is the assistance given to sport, recreation and tourism. Having recently briefly visited North America as a member of a parliamentary delegation, I was very impressed with the success of our tourist promotion campaign. The program run in the United States with Paul Hogan has had a tremendous impact on tourism. The Minister at the table, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, the Hon. J. J. Brown, deserves full praise for what he has done with tourism in the United States. The Consul- General in San Francisco told me of the large increase in applications for tourist visas to enter Australia, due to the campaign. Everywhere I went Americans spoke about Paul Hogan's ads, about putting an extra shrimp on the barbie. I believe that the real growth area of employment for young people in our nation is tourism. The potential for employing young girls, young men, students and part time workers in the tourist industry is great and the Government has realised this. It is taking action to promote tourism throughout the world and it is the North American market that we must look to. I think the Government has done great things there. The Budget increases aid to this area and I give the Minister full praise for this.

There is also stimulation in the Budget for the work of the Australia Council. Much comment appears in the Press about videos. It is good to see that Australians are at last taking an interest in what the children of our nation are watching. One-third of the population are children and they watch television at great length. From my experience I know that they watch mainly American, British and other overseas comedies and that very little of the television shown to them is Australian produced. We have the capacity. We have a thriving film industry, but we have very little impact on the market for youth and children. Our directors, our artists and our actors have the talent and we have the creativity, and we certainly have the tax concessional support from government. When one looks at theatre, it is very difficult for a parent to find suitable theatre or drama for children during the school holidays. We are now in school holidays, and that can be seen by glancing at the gallery and seeing the large number of families who visit this Parliament and Canberra; and they are very welcome.

There should be more emphasis by our heavily subsidised theatre on providing entertainment for children and young people during the school holidays. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation is to be commended for its children's drama and television productions. It produces programs such as Play School particularly for preschool children. It employs the very best actors and actresses to perform in these dramas. The hardest group to entertain and stimulate is young children; any school teacher will attest to that. The really hard work is with infants, where for every moment attention has to be focused on the audience. I congratulate the Nimrod Theatre in Sydney and other groups for what they are doing in drama for young people. I am sure they really appreciate the financial assistance from this Government, previous governments and the State governments; but it is essential that more emphasis be placed on obtaining access to the one-third of Australians who are under the age of 15. These young people deserve more attention. I am sure that the continuing aid from this Government to drama, theatre and films will go more and more to this important area.

As to other matters in the Budget, quite significant aid in the social welfare and social security areas is going to child care. The Government's children's services program will increase from $113m in 1983-84 to about $158m this year. It is a very significant increase. Any member of this House or of the Senate knows of the problems constituents have in obtaining a place for long day care and the problems of working women who are confronted with going out to work and finding that most of the money they earn goes to pay child care facilities for one or two children in a long day care centre. I congratulate the Treasurer on increasing finance for child care facilities by more than 60 per cent in two years.

In my electorate, some children start school unable to speak English. The need for child care is paramount because teachers are not trained to teach English to children. They are trained to teach them other things such as how to read and write. There is an art in teaching English to little children, and if they can go to a preschool to learn English this greatly helps the school system in both government and non-government schools.

The Government has established a new home and community care program. This will be negotiated between the States and the Northern Territory to provide care to the aged and to young disabled people. This is a very important initiative, and Commonwealth expenditure on this program will be $300m over the next three years . It is important that old people and disabled people are able to remain in their homes and are not forced out of the home situation into a nursing home or full time care.

I hope that the Government will do something about the funeral benefit which has been pegged at, I think, $40 for many years-since 1943. Fortunately, it has not been removed, although the previous Government tried to abolish it. It concerns me that only $20 is payable to an organisation such as the Salvation Army or the St Vincent de Paul Society for the burial of a pauper. I feel that the amount is not relevant these days. I was interested in the reply to a question I asked of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) on this issue, following representations from the St Vincent de Paul Society, which has a large paupers plot at Rookwood Cemetery adjoining my electorate.

The Government is to be commended for the assistance it is giving in the Budget to the Aboriginal community. There has been an increase of 14 per cent to $234m in the vote for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The Treasurer pointed out that priority will be given to improving water, sewerage, housing, and other services for Aboriginal communities, including fringe dwellers. Any member of this House or any Australian who has visited the areas in our nation where Aborigines comprise the majority of the population will know of some of the problems that these people experience. I have visited the Kimberleys in Western Australia and Bourke, Brewarrina and other parts of New South Wales. I was appalled in the Kimberleys to find that Aborigines suffer from leprosy, a disease that I believed in my innocence did not exist in our rich and prosperous nation. I have learned that leprosy is a result only of appalling living conditions over a long period; it is not a disease which is easily transmitted from one human being to another.

I was saddened by what I saw, and I support the Government in its initiatives to help the Aboriginal community to provide decent water, which we in the cities of Canberra, Sydney and Melbourne and elsewhere take for granted, sewerage facilities, and decent housing so that people can live with dignity as a family. I commend the Government for what it is doing in this regard, and I know that Australian people will support the Government in its efforts to help the Aboriginal community. No matter what opposition is raised I know that the Australian people will ultimately support the Aborigines, as they did in the great referendum in 1967, when every electorate in Australia voted to assist the Aboriginal community.

Another matter I wish to touch on briefly is the housing aid the Government has given to our young people through the first home owners scheme. This has been important in helping the families in our nation. It has had a significant impact in urban and even in rural areas of our country. For the first time 80,000 families have been able to buy their own home. In this day and age they have received really significant aid to buy a home. It is very important that people have access to buying a home of their own, and I commend the work done by the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford).

To touch briefly on the Government's capital expenditure and works program, my colleague the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) has pointed out to me that the Government's development of the Burdekin Dam, which was promised by every previous Liberal government but not acted upon, is the largest water resources program since the Snowy Mountains scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolute rot. The previous Government started the Burdekin Dam .

—No matter what our opponents might say, the Labor Government, to its credit, is building the Burdekin Dam. Labor has developed the Townsville Airport and developed the Northern Territory RAAF base. Only the Labor Government will actually fulfil its promises. If anything, it should be called the Lindsay Dam, after the honourable member for Herbert, whose hard work has got that dam underway.

SPEECH.PARA: Another area I want to touch on is the important area of assistance to the motor vehicle industry. We have a five-year program for Australian design and research activities. At Homebush, in my electorate, the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd has a most successful plant where it is producing the very popular Laser motor car. Last year when I visited the plant and inspected facilities it was taking on 50 employees a month, despite the recession. It was taking on people mainly who did not speak English. It was taking advantage of Government's schemes to employ the long term unemployed. I praise Ford and I know that where it has a good product it will be very successful.

The Government is taking a number of steps to stimulate trade with Japan, China and the North American markets. I pay full tribute to the Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen). Having just visited a number of countries both as a member of a parliamentary delegation and at my own expense, I know of the work of the Trade officers and our consular officers overseas, whose job it is to stimulate interest in Australian trade. There are many problems. There are long term problems for Australia with the developments in iron ore in Brazil that will be coming on to schedule in a few years time. Our Trade people are outstanding representatives of Australia. They are very sensitive people who do everything they can to promote their nation.

I must move quickly as my time is fast expiring. I congratulate the Treasurer on amending the requirements relating to the bank accounts debit tax which was introduced by the previous Government and which for some reason always affected parents and citizens associations. I am pleased that this onerous tax has been removed and no longer has to be paid by parents and citizens organisations, by parents and friends organisations or by non-business local councils and government bodies. It was a very silly tax. Local councils which ran any sort of trading activity had to pay tax on their accounts.

Another matter I wish to touch on is the Government's program for the unemployed. That is probably the final matter I will have a chance to mention. I refer to the work of the Government in stimulating employment and the work of those involved in the community youth support scheme, which fortunately is now underway in Burwood in my electorate. I give full praise to all of the local people who launched this scheme. It is very unfortunate to be unemployed and many of the fringe benefits available to pensioners do not go on to the long term unemployed. I am talking about young people and older people, migrants who do not speak English and cannot get a job once they reach the age of 55. I congratulate the Government on the outstanding Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Budget provides a good opportunity to take a hard look at Medicare after six months in operation and when a full year's estimates of the costs of Medicare are available for the first time. We can and will judge Medicare against the claims made for it by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett). Also, because the Government has now been in office for 17 months we are in a good position to judge its overall performance in the administration of the Department of Health. The Prime Minister, in his 1983 policy speech, made the following commitment:

SPEECH.PARA: 9 out of 10 Australians will pay less for the health needs of themselves and their families.
The Prime Minister, in his letter to all Australians, before the introduction of Medicare, had already and characteristically shortchanged the public on his policy speech commitment when he said:
Two out of three families will be paying less for the cover that they now enjoy .

So he had gone from nine out of 10 Australians to two out of three families. In practice, the Government has delivered on neither of these promises. Individuals and families who have decided to maintain the same degree of private insurance cover which they had before are, in the majority of cases, worse off than they were before. They pay their one per cent Medicare levy on all their family incomes and on top of that they pay a private health insurance premium. They have lost the tax rebate they used to enjoy on their basic health insurance contributions. They are prevented by law from insuring to cover the gap between the schedule fee for medical services and the Medicare rebate. Therefore they have to meet this expense each time they visit the doctor. They have lost the benefit of a $80m hospital reinsurance subsidy. So despite the fact that they might have insured privately for years, they are restricted in the number of days they can stay in hospital without incurring serious out-of-pocket expenses. Many of those who are privately insured are simply not aware of this restriction , and that is of particular concern to the elderly.

The claim that nine out of 10 Australians or two out of three families, whichever claim we believe, will pay less for the same cover was always a fraudulent claim. The Government had no capacity to deliver on this promise, and I take no pleasure in pointing out that millions of Australian families have been cheated by the Prime Minister, the Minister for Health and the Australian Labor Party. Let us examine another Medicare claim. The Medicare leaflet states:
Medicare will be paid for by a 1% levy on your taxable income.

Again, this claim is simply untrue. As the Budget Papers demonstrate, the one per cent levy on taxable incomes will raise, we are told, $1,191m in 1984-85. That is approximately $1.2 billion. I estimate that the total cost of our health system to Federal and State governments will be somewhere between $9 billion and $10 billion, of which the Commonwealth will provide $5.5 billion from taxpayers' funds in this financial year. So the Medicare levy of one per cent pays for about one-eighth of total Government expenditures on health, both Federal and State, or about one-fifth of the Federal expenditures. On any reasonable definition of Medicare expenditures, the claim that the levy pays in total for such expenditures is fraudulent. Were such a claim made by a private organisation in the course of business the proprietors would be prosecuted under the Trade Practices Act. If it were in a prospectus, which is more akin to the Medicare literature, those responsible would be prosecuted under section 125 or 126 of the Securities Industry Code.

Let me take the most charitable interpretation of the claim that Medicare will be paid for by the one per cent levy. The narrowest possible definition of the costs of Medicare would be the increase in medical and hospital benefits resulting from the nationalisation effects of Medicare. The Budget Papers tell us that medical and hospital benefits have risen by $2,021m, compared with the old scheme. The levy brings in $1,191m, leaving a shortfall of $830m. Thus a secret additional levy of $830m, equivalent to 0.7 per cent of taxable personal income, is being taken from taxpayers to pay for Medicare, even on this narrowest definition of additional costs. It is clear that the one per cent levy relates to no particular expenditure. It is a meaningless figure in all but one sense, and that sense is its role in creating an illusion of low cost for our national health.

The Minister's commitment to maintain the levy at one per cent is therefore quite meaningless. While he takes our money openly at the counter, at the same time he is secretly milking our bank accounts of the funds he needs to keep the shop open. People did not realise that the plastic Medicare card was not a guarantee of health care; rather is it the Hawke Government's version of instant money transfer, secretly transmitting money from the taxpayer to the Treasury.

Let us take a look at the weekly effect of Medicare on the finances of a family which has maintained its private hospital cover after the advent of Medicare. I give as an example a family consisting of a man, earning the average weekly male earnings for Sydney of $384 a week, with a dependent spouse. I have taken that example just to get that income figure but I could take the double income family or any combination of incomes adding up to $384 a week. The average weekly cost of health insurance on the most commonly used private table of three major funds in New South Wales, after deduction of the 30c in the dollar tax rebate applying before Medicare and allowing for the consumer price index adjustments to insurance rates to bring them up to an assumed May 1984 level, was $11.56 a week for that family.

After Medicare the average weekly cost of the three funds for the same level of private cover excluding medical cover, which is now covered by the levy, is $8. 77. Of course there is no tax rebate. Add to this the one per cent Medicare levy of $3.84 a week plus the secret levy of 0.7 per cent, that is $2.69, and we get a weekly outlay in total of $15.30 against the original $11.56. Thus the additional cost to that family is $3.74 a week. I have not taken into account the likely additional cost of meeting the uninsurable gap between the schedule fee and the Medicare rebate for medical services, which could add quite substantially to the extra costs if there was chronic illness in such a family. Some might ask why we should continue with private hospital insurance when the Medicare leaflet told us:
If you go to a public hospital, Medicare will provide free accommodation and treatment by doctors appointed by the hospital.

One obvious reason why people would want to maintain private cover is that they would wish to choose their own doctor or to change their doctor if they were dissatisfied. Anyone who has gone through a period of serious illness and has not been totally satisfied with the attention received will understand why so many people consider being able to choose their doctor worth the extra insurance cost. However, those who have met the extra cost rightly become infuriated when they find that a person on equal or greater income who has not insured privately is charged nothing for a public hospital bed, while the insured person, through his or her insurance fund, is charged $80 a day by the same public hospital for the same kind of bed.

If one lives in a country area not served by a public hospital one is in real trouble. The Government made no arrangements to provide for Medicare patients in community hospitals such as bush nursing hospitals before making its fraudulent promises to provide care on the production of the card.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they pay the same taxes and the same Medicare levy.

—As my friend the honourable member for Murray says, those in country areas pay exactly the same taxes and levy but they do not get any service. Even in areas served by public hospitals the promise of a free bed is not always met. The bed may be free, but it is available only at the end of a queue. In Victoria at the moment there are 8,000 patients on waiting lists for public hospitals. I visited the City of Ballarat recently. Four hundred patients were on the waiting list for the Ballarat Base Hospital, all uninsured patients, all coming along with their Medicare cards and wanting to receive the service promised to them by the Federal Minister for Health. They are still on that waiting list. Before Medicare, there was no waiting list at the Ballarat Base Hospital. Now there is a waiting list of 400, all uninsured, mostly elderly, sick people. There is a good private hospital at Ballarat, the St John of God Hospital, which could accommodate these people. People who have given up private insurance are going to the public hospital and taking the place of those pensioners and the poor.

SPEECH.PARA: A two-year waiting list for orthopaedic work in public hospitals is reminiscent of what has happened in the British national health scheme. It provides free health at the end of a queue for the poor and the inarticulate. The organised and the articulate will manipulate the system to get ahead of the queue. Influence is used. That same influence is being used every day already in Australia to get around the Medicare rules. I know of many people who are doing that. Those who can afford private insurance are occupying the beds that the poor and the inarticulate cannot obtain. Those who are most in need are left out in the cold. The promise of a free bed is fraudulent. The $80 charge to the insured is unfair under our 'simplest and fairest health scheme ever'. The Health Minister in his letter to those compulsorily enrolled congratulated them on becoming members of this compulsory scheme and said:
You are now enrolled with Medicare, the simplest and fairest health insurance scheme Australia has ever had.

Is Medicare simple? Whereas previously Australians could get all their health insurance in the one place at the one shop, if they now wish to continue with private health cover they have two-stop shopping. They have to go to the private health insurance office and also to a Medicare office. Medicare offices are few and far between. We heard this morning the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) point out that in the north of New South Wales people have to go hundreds of kilometres if they wish to attend a Medicare office; otherwise, they have to depend on the decrepit Post Office. Is Medicare fair? The chronically ill cannot insure for the gap. They find it difficult to pay for the gap. There is a $150 limit, but it applies only to individual patients. If there are a number of children in a family it is necessary for each one to get to the limit before claiming the 100 per cent rebate. In addition, we find that this is administratively complicated. Unless one pays the full bill with the receipt before going to the Medicare office it is devilishly complicated to get that gap recorded in the computer. If it is not recorded, it does not apply.

Is it fair when the elderly and the chronically ill, after years of membership of funds, find that because of the reduction in the government reinsurance subsidy of $80m they have not complete private cover as they expected? When they are most in need they find that there are limits to the number of days that they are privately covered, even though they have paid into funds for years. Is it fair when the long term sick, many of them elderly, are forced out of public or private hospitals under the 35-day rule or have to pay a great deal out of pocket? Is it fair that doctors are threatened with a $5,000 fine or five years in gaol if they incorrectly sign the section 3B form under the 35-day rule to say whether or not a person is in need of acute care? This 35-day rule was based on economics that appeared to be sound, but it was brought in without any plan as to where these people are to go if they have to leave the private or public hospital after the 35 days have expired.

In a provincial hospital just recently, I was told that the administration found the covering of the section 3B certificates almost impossible administratively. The patients themselves were ticking off the 35 days and asking each day how many days they had to go. That is cruel to those kinds of people. The rule was brought in as an economic measure without any concern for its effect on people. At the same time, there has been a freeze for 15 months on nursing home bed approvals. New guidelines have now come in; they are almost impossible for anybody to comply with. In effect, there is still a freeze on new nursing homes. The extra domiciliary support that was promised is non-existent. Chronic psychiatric patients are being forced into astonishing expense because of the categorisation of private hospitals and the fact that the subsidies for their beds have been reduced. Thus, Medicare is not cheap; it is not simple; and it is not fair. It has been fraudulently advertised and incompetently and cruelly administered. Medicare is a giant step towards the nationalisation of health.

Medicare is also damaging the whole system of health care delivery, built up to a very high standard over the last century. It is destroying the motivation of those working in the system to provide good service and to achieve excellence. Public hospital budgets have been squeezed to the point of inefficiency, poor patient service, and loss of staff morale. Private medical practitioners, whose contribution to health care is a vital ingredient of the quality of the Australian system, have been attacked professionally and financially and subjected to unwarranted abuse by the Prime Minister, who compared them with the Builders Labourers Federation, and by the Federal Health Minister and Labor State health Ministers.

Medicare has provoked the first doctors' strike in Australia's history and State legislation to complement Medicare has led to mass resignations by doctors . Bulk billing by doctors has been extended beyond necessity, turning doctors into employees of the Government rather than professional consultants to the patients, reducing doctors' incomes quite unfairly and tempting patients and doctors into excessive use of medical services. The campaign against fraud and over-servicing has been turned into a crusade, with the vast majority of doctors going about their work ethically and professionally feeling threatened and unjustly tarnished in popular esteem. Private hospitals have been brought under arbitrary Federal control by a categorisation scheme that has no logic with the threat of financial loss and ultimate nationalisation.

By discouraging self-provision and increasing the proportion of health funding provided by the taxpayer and also by removing disincentives to overuse of services at the doctor-patient level, Federal and State Labor governments have created a system that has become obsessed with cost at the expense of quality, security and comfort. With fewer private dollars going into the system and with more calls in the Budget to meet health costs, Labor governments have centralised control and tightened the screw on expenses without knowledge of, or regard for, real patient needs. This is a system run by bureaucrats and bookkeepers without feeling for the patients, the doctors, the nurses or other health professionals and health workers who have to make the system work.

What has this Budget done to deal with the problems that have become evident during the first six months of Medicare? It is painfully clear that the poor, the sick and the elderly were not present when the Australian Council of Trade Unions dictated the outline of the Budget. Under the accord, Medicare is required to provide free services, so called, to many who could afford to take out private insurance, leaving the poor and the elderly in a queue.

The Budget is notable for the absence of measures to deal with these problems caused by Medicare. No special provision is made for reducing queues of uninsured patients in public hospitals to help the 8,000 on waiting lists in Victoria alone. The hospital reinsurance subsidy, cut from $100m to $20m last year, remains at $20m for 1984-85, a cut in real terms of about 6 per cent. It is the cut in reinsurance subsidy that has forced the health funds to limit the hospital cover of contributors to a set number of days each year.
