SPEECH.PARA: I want to talk about some of the comments by Opposition spokesmen on the Budget because they have stretched credulity a bit too far. The Australian Labor Party has been in government for four and a half years since 1949. Suddenly, all the problems of the economy are of our creation. It seems to be forgotten-the Opposition seems to assume that people have fairly short memories-that when we came into government this country faced the worst economic situation since the Depression. If anyone does not believe that we are still in a serious economic situation, he has not seriously examined the economy. This Government has made extremely satisfactory progress in turning around the economy. Our achievements have been remarkable.

Last night the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) suddenly discovered a lot of economic rectitude, as though the previous Government, of which he was a member, did nothing to create the economic situation that we face. He conveniently ignored the monstrous deficit that we inherited. He conveniently ignored the fact that the tax cuts at the end of Mr Fraser's regime were partially responsible for the deficit that we now have. One of this morning's newspapers has picked up the fundamental dishonesty of his comments. We were left with a massive deficit. We are trying to turn around the economy and our achievements have been remarkable.

Let us look at the legacy of the Fraser Government-'small government Fraser' and 'small spending John'. The total debt for the Commonwealth at the change of government in 1975 was $20.338 billion. The interest liability at that time was $1.371 billion. At the end of the life of the Fraser Government the debt stood at $39.128 billion. It virtually doubled in seven years. We now have to pay-and this is contained in the Budget documents-$5.6 billion a year for Mr Fraser's profligacy, and to pay for the resources boom which was pushed down our throats and which never eventuated. Due to Mr Fraser's profligacy, the amount that the Australian taxpayers must pay is now about 7 per cent of gross domestic product.

The Opposition says that the tax cut is illusory, but at the same time we must lower the deficit. So where would it obtain the money? Would it wipe out Medicare? Would it wipe out the money that we are spending on housing, education , employment and social security? Those areas cannot be quarantined or isolated from the rural sector. Is the National Party saying that it would spend money in its particular so-called specialist areas, but it would rely on its Liberal colleagues, if they ever return to the Treasury benches, to wipe out all of the spending in other areas that hurts people in Australia, wherever they may live. So on the one hand the opposition says that the Budget deficit should be lower, and on the other it makes profligate promises.

Total spending on agricultural and pastoral industries in this year's Budget is estimated to be $316.8m, an increase of $45.5m or 16.8 per cent. Using the same calculations, the mining and manufacturing industry sectors receive a combined amount of $305.6m. The big one-off drop in expenditure this year in regard to primary industries was for drought relief, which has been lowered by $29.2m. We all welcome that fact. It is very difficult to obtain an accurate basis for comparison of year to year expenditure by governments on Australia's agricultural and pastoral industries because of one-off factors such as loans, collections of levies, repayments and disbursements. However, if one consistently and honestly isolates expenditure that distorts the calculations to try to calculate a consistent figure for net expenditure by the Commonwealth, the following figures are produced: In 1981-82 net expenditure was $151.16m; in 1982-83 the figure was $167.5m; and in 1983-84-the first year of the Hawke Government and the first Keating Budget-the figure was $182.7m. This year the calculation is an amount of $211.8m. So expenditure in the agricultural and pastoral industries is increasing gradually and consistently. In other words, there has been no cut by this Government. If we include in the calculation some of the one-off items, such as drought interest rate subsidies, expenditure would be increased substantially.

All sorts of comparisons can be given. One comparison of expenditure that was given to me by the Department of Primary Industry-it is not my calculation; it was calculated by the Department-gave net outlays under the previous Government. The lowest was in 1979-80, with a figure of about $78m and the highest was in 1982-83, which included drought subsidies, of $248m. I concede that these figures are distorted but they were calculated on the same base. This calculation shows not only the distortion but also the fact that outlays under the coalition parties varied widely. That is understandable.

But let us return to the two-card trick. The Liberal Party says that it wants small government and small spending. But it does not say how this can be achieved. It says the tax cuts are illusory, but it does not say that it will give a tax cut which is double or treble the amount which we have given. The National Party says that the deficit is too large. But it has recently brought out its policy document on agricultural industries which gives, on a conservative estimate, an extra $312m. The Leader of the Liberal Party has agreed with this document. In his comments last night he implied that the figure would be even higher-at least an additional $30m. The National Party composed this document by consulting with rural organisations and composing a wish list. I have analysed the document. It consists of 54 general paragraphs which are uncontentious and contain articles of faith and propaganda-one cannot avoid having motherhood statements in such a document-and 108 specific paragraphs. Sixty-six refer to matters which have been or are being carried out by the present Government or which are not contentious. Seventeen paragraphs use the words 'review', 'encourage', 'if', and 'then', all of which invite the response 'how?'. Two are repetitive, three contradictory and seven complete nonsense, impossible or meaningless. That leaves 13 which are substantive. That is the way I arrived at my figure of $312m extra.

First of all, the payment for all export inspection would cost $45.45m. The boost to research and promotion funds would cost a minimum of $5m. The underwriting for the sugar industry would cost $173.27m if one assumes that the Opposition would adopt the Joint Industry Sugar Group's underwriting formula.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was in 1982 though.
—The additional fertiliser subsidies would cost a minimum of $1m.
—You are being dishonest.

—The honourable member had better tell me what formula the Opposition is to use for underwriting sugar. What will be the period? What pools will it underwrite? Will it go for gross or net? What will be the basis of the underwriting scheme? There is no sense promising an underwriting scheme--
—Your candidate did.
—I did not. That is an absolute lie.
—Your candidate in north Queensland promised an underwriting scheme in 1982 and I can prove it.
—The honourable member promised sugar for the Ord.
—I did not; that is a lie.

—If the Opposition is to promise an underwriting scheme for the sugar industry it has to lay down what is the basis for that scheme. Let us go on to other promises. The reintroduction of income equalisation deposits would imply a revenue loss of at least $4m. We do not know whether the Opposition would go back to an opt-in opt-out situation which would push it up substantially more. It would cut out threshold payments by the States for drought. That would cost $ 28.225m. Increased funds for drought research would cost $4m. Additional funds for soil conservation would cost $6m. To provide $2 for $1 for research would cost at least $20m. The increase in funds to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation would cost $5m. The extra money for wool promotion would cost $5m. Feral animal programs would cost $5m. Adjustment support for fishing would cost a minimum of $10m. This adds up to $312m. This small spending coalition, on top of the net figure this year which can be variously estimated at anything from $211m to $316.8m, would spend an extra $ 312m.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the two-card trick. The Opposition can say what it wants to say to one interest group and it can talk at the same time about a lower deficit. It can say that tax cuts are illusory, which is nonsense. What the National Party policy reflects is the old handout philosophy, the old idea that to give tax deductibility makes people feel warm inside. It assumes that they have income from which expenditure can be deducted. We know that National Party philosophy is populism. It is the Muldoon approach. We know what a mess he landed New Zealand in. The Opposition has no idea that a government should not be indulging in handouts to the rural sector. It should get into some concept of investment in the future. It should try to invest in those areas of the primary industry sector where there is a long term benefit. It should not provide palliatives to solve immediate issues. It should not give a handout because one part of the sector squeaks; it should have some long term idea about the whole sector across the board. It is areas such as promotion, research and resources into which government investment, the people's investment should go. The National Party did nothing about soil conservation. The National Party in New South Wales at the last election said that it was for the States and it should be settled by tax deductibility if the Commonwealth got involved. The Leader of the National Party said the same thing in a debate in the House. Let us look at resources in the fishing industry. The Ministers for primary industry in the coalition-the Ministers always came from the National Party-did nothing about resources in the fishing industry. Even when stocks had almost reached the point of depletion they still did nothing.

This Budget sets out to capitalise on the growth in the economy. Under the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that growth is calculated to increase by 4.4 per cent. Investment will rise; interest rates will come down; employment will go up. We have the lowest inflation for 10 years and the prices and incomes accord will give us a period from April 1984 to April 1985 without any wage rises through the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Under the Fraser Government there was a big wage blowout in 1980-81 of over 14 per cent. There will be no more of that. This Budget is investing in the basics of our primary producing industries so that we can get the industry on a better basis. A reduction in costs is vital if our agricultural and pastoral industries are to survive. It is this reduction in costs that will keep our primary industries internationally competitive and nothing is more important for those industries than the work that this Government is doing with the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer him to the Budget announcement that there will be a record level of Commonwealth borrowing overseas in 1984-85 because of the Government's decision to have the highest ever overseas deficit of $2.9 billion in the current Budget. Is the Government increasing its overseas borrowings by $378m while reducing its domestic borrowings by $1.6 billion simply to window-dress the impact of its excessive Budget deficit on Australian money markets? As government capital spending overseas this year is rising by only $146m to $1.5 billion, equal to about half the level of overseas borrowings, what is the Government's justification for disregarding concerns already expressed by leading commentators about Australia' s excessive dependence on overseas borrowing? Why is the Government borrowing twice as much from overseas as it is spending overseas on capital items?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I must refer to the disastrous fiscal inheritance left to this Government by the former Government. To bring the monetary policy in on target for the first time in six years, as this Government did to 30 June, we had to sell a lot of Commonwealth bonds not only to finance the Budget deficit, which was as high as it was last year because of the disastrous policies of the former Government, but also, as I said yesterday to the Leader of the Opposition, to mop up the $4,000m of capital inflow to Australia in the first half of the financial year 1983-84.

ANSWER.PARA: That factor, plus the fact of the grossed bond selling program for 1983-84, does have consequences in terms of the amount of Commonwealth paper which the market is prepared to digest. The Government took the view that as we had a record addition to our foreign reserves as a result of that capital inflow in the first part of 1983-84, and given the earnings which our foreign reserves will in fact accrue, the Government is in the position this year, if it chooses to-we will be looking at this as we move through the year-to run down our foreign reserves, particularly to the extent of the interest earnings upon that capital inflow. Floating of Australian dollar reserves of that order would permit the Government to run them down somewhat and, coupled with the normal kind of borrowing program overseas, which the Commonwealth Government has had under a succession of governments, that would permit a substantial proportion, if not all, of the funding of the overseas deficit in 1984-85.

One could argue in theory that if we are not selling another $2.5 billion or $2 .9 billion worth of bonds in the local market to fund the foreign exchange purchases for the satisfaction of the overseas deficit, it is also true to say that we are not funding that amount of liquidity in the economy. So theoretically there should be no change in interest rates in terms of the fact that we are not pumping $2.9 billion in and we are not taking $2.9 billion out. The problem is that the market has to digest so many bonds owing to the disastrous policies of my predecessor. Since we had such a tremendous addition to reserves in 1983-84, the Government thinks that for this year-I emphasise this year-it would be prudent on the Commonwealth's part to run down reserves and borrow abroad in satisfaction of all or part of the overseas deficit.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Housing and Construction and ask him whether he has noted industry reaction to the changes in the first home owners scheme? If so, what is his response?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can tell the honourable member for Brisbane that I have noted the responses of the industry in this matter of changes to the first home owners scheme. I am delighted to be able to add, both for his benefit and for the benefit of the House, that the reactions have been excellent and most helpful. The Federal President of the Real Estate Institute of Australia, Mr Malcolm Gray , applauded the housing measures in the Budget. The federal office of the Housing Industry Association headlined its Press release: 'Budget brightens interest rate outlook'. The South Australian office of the Housing Industry Association is quoted as commending the Government for continuing the first home owners scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: Certainly some disappointment was expressed at the need to change the first home owners scheme, yet the need for change, as outlined in the statements to which I have referred, was understood. All of this was in the face of articles which were published before the Budget, which were based on rumours and which were frankly quite inaccurate. I ask the people who wrote those articles to go back over what they wrote and to recognise that perhaps before commenting on the next Budget they should be a little more responsible.

These informed commentators to whom I have referred recognise three things: Firstly, the wisdom of the Government's overall economic strategy-how cutting the deficit is going to help the housing industry because it will take pressure off interest rates, which is enormously important for the housing industry. Secondly, they recognise that expenditure on the first home owners scheme in the 1984-85 financial year, will be $265m, as opposed to $141m for the first nine months of the scheme in the last financial year. Thirdly, they recognise that in 1984-85 80,000 people in Australia will be helped through the first home owners scheme compared with 55,000 helped during the enormously successful nine months from 1 October last. So that is the responsible outlook. I am pleased to say that responsible leaders of the housing industry recognise that in the statements they have put out. It is very important that they should recognise it because confidence is enormously important to the housing industry.

Unfortunately, there has been one exception to this, and I need to draw attention to it. That one exception is the New South Wales President of the Real Estate Institute, a Mr Chris Scott, and the best thing I can say for him is that he has a good first name.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with his second name?

—Down in Hindmarsh they reckon he has a good second name too, but his first name is particularly good. His statement was based on half knowledge, and it led to the Sydney Daily Telegraph yesterday printing something which was inaccurate and damaging. It put on its front page a statement headed: 'Hundreds miss out on homes cash'. The article went on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: Hundreds of young couples will be unable to go ahead with plans.

There is not one young couple in this country which will be disadvantaged, other than in a very minor way, under the changes to the first home owners scheme. The Sydney Daily Telegraph has now acknowledged that what it meant to say was 'young singles', not 'young couples'. Members of the Opposition should follow the details of this scheme. They are merely showing that they have about as much interest now in housing schemes in this country as they have displayed in the past 17 months. Since I have been Minister for Housing and Construction there has been one question on housing from the Opposition in this Parliament. I pay tribute to the honourable member for Paterson, who in April 1983 asked the last question from the Opposition on housing. Of course, the Opposition's policies on housing are attested to by the fact that when we took over the government of this country, the housing commencement rate was running at 105,000 -a 20-year low.

Every couple in this country will have an entitlement under the first home owners scheme after the Budget, as was the case before the Budget. I admit there will be some reduction in benefits because of the tapering above $20,000, but it is still available up to the same income limit of $27,900.

I want the industry and the Parliament to know that we shall be continue to monitor this industry closely. It is going well in South Australia, Western Australia and Victoria. There is some slight downturn, for one month anyway, in New South Wales and Queensland, but we shall continue to monitor it. Not only will we do that but also we will make alterations if they are needed. However, we can do without inaccurate articles such as this one. We can do without damaging statements such as we had from that New South Wales President. All I can say is that some people in the private sector are their own worst enemies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can he inform the House what the reaction of the business community has been to Tuesday night's Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a generally favourable reaction by the business community to the Budget, I am pleased to report. One of the best ways of demonstrating that is that the all ordinaries index on the stock exchanges rose by 12.5 points to 751.9 points, while the all industrials rose by 11.2 to 1,041. This means that the all ordinaries index was more than 240 points higher than in March 1983 and the all industrials was more than 390 points higher. I will quote from various newspapers. The Australian Financial Review said that the market was being 'led by the favourable Budget news and a rally in Wall Street'. The Australian said that 'several brokers pointed to the Government's tax incentives to the exploration industry and reductions in company charges as bull points contained in the Budget'. The Age said:

ANSWER.PARA: Prices jumped on Australian sharemarkets yesterday as investors took heart from the good news Budget.
The Sydney Morning Herald said:
Mr Keating was the toast of the Australian stock exchanges yesterday.

That is a point of view with which I heartily concur. All in all, the reaction of the business community was very favourable. The Australian newspaper reported that in a telephone poll which it conducted 52.8 per cent of chief executives or financial controllers believed that the Budget would maintain the economic recovery, while only 7.9 per cent said they thought it would jeopardise it. Those were the ones with their Liberal Party tickets in their pockets. I will also quote some of the major business groups. Sir Arvi Parbo, representing the Business Council of Australia, said:
With all the positive signs in the economy and given the need to reduce the deficit this implied no adverse changes in investment conditions.
The Budget proposals relating to investment have, on the whole, achieved this.

Mr Don Hughes from the Confederation of Australian Industry said that the 1984- 85 Budget was notable for the lack of disruption it would cause to business operations. This, he said, had not been the case in recent years. Mr David Abba of the Sydney Chamber of Commerce said he was pleased to see that the Government was making an effort to boost business confidence in the Australian economy. I did not see any impartial comments from Mr Alan Jones or Mr Alexander Downer on this occasion. They were too busy running around chasing their Liberal Party preselections. Normally we have come to expect and are used to their impartial comments on Government policy.

The Housing Industry Association also said that it welcomed reductions in the Budget deficit, combined with Australia's improved inflation outlook. It set the scene for lower interest rates. On interest rates, which are a pretty fair guide in the market to the reaction to the Budget, rates continued to fall on money markets in the wake of the Budget. According to the Australian Financial Review, buyers of Commonwealth Bonds appear to be convinced that rates will continue to ease. Ten-year Government bonds are now trading at 12.6 per cent, down from 13. 85 per cent at the end of last financial year and 14.4 per cent at the end of March 1983, while 180-day bank bills, to which I referred a couple of days ago, were 10.8 per cent yesterday compared with 15.75 per cent in March 1983. I also mention that two days ago Treasury notes fell by around one per cent-on Wednesday, after the Budget. Thirteen-week notes closed at 9.735, while 26-week notes were down to 10.086. So we have not only a rally on the stock market, favourable comments from the business organisations and falls in interest rates, but also the Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research, in its latest survey of consumer confidence, indicates that consumer confidence in the economy has soared to its highest level for more than 12 years, when the survey was first started.
I conclude by quoting Don Stammer, an economist, formerly with the Reserve Bank of Australia and now with Bain and Co., who gives a very learned commentary on the economy, and who said:
Overall the Budget was sensible and balanced with a manageable deficit- deserving of many marks out of 10.

I will leave members of the Parliament to make their own judgment of the reaction of the business community in terms of the stock market, informed comment and interest rates. It is something upon which the Liberal Party may well ponder.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Primary Industry whether, since the Hawke Government came to power in March 1983, incomes and employment in grape growing areas have improved?
—No.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport. Given the high proportion of deaths from head injuries amongst bicyclists and the obvious benefit of reducing this loss of life by the wearing of helmets, does the Minister recall giving an undertaking to the Peninsula Road Safety Committee in the Flinders electorate during his visit there on 2 August 1984 to examine the position on sales tax on helmets? If so, can the Minister inform the House whether sales tax is payable on bicycle helmets and can he inform the House of the ways in which people can be further encouraged to wear them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Flinders for his question and for the courtesy extended to me during my visit to his electorate on the date he mentioned. The Government is particularly concerned about the number of fatalities among cyclists, particularly among children. Of the hundred cyclists who have died or are expected to die on our roads this year, about two-thirds are children. Of the number of fatalities among cyclists, four out of five of them are the result of head injuries. So the point that the honourable member raised is very important. If more cyclists can be convinced of the need to wear protective helmets, obviously the casualty rate will be reduced.

ANSWER.PARA: As I undertook to do in my discussions with the Peninsula Road Safety Committee in the honourable member's electorate, I have sought advice on whether sales tax is applicable to approved protective safety helmets for bicyclists and I am advised that they are not eligible for sales tax. That helps to reduce the cost, but the cost still ranges from some $30 to $50. If a family with young children purchases a bicycle the added cost of a helmet becomes a major item. If more than one bicycle is being bought by a family it becomes an even greater item. There are ways of overcoming that problem. One thing which impressed me during my recent visit to the Flinders electorate was that the Peninsula Road Safety Committee has encouraged groups within the schools to join together in buying groups to buy on a co-operative basis. That has resulted in a considerable reduction in the price of helmets, but even then the price is still considerable . If community groups and other communities could follow the example set by the Peninsula Road Safety Committee in Frankston I am sure that a substantial reduction could be made in the level of casualties among bike riders. I wish to take this opportunity to remind the House of the priority this Government attaches to road safety and to the development of our road networks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, why did you tax low alcohol beer? You are driving people away from it.

—The honourable member is aware that the tax on light beer was reduced. I will now get back to the issue I was discussing. As I was saying, I wish to remind the House of the very important priority we attach to improving road conditions and road safety. That is evidenced by the 31 per cent increase in expenditure for road safety promotion and research.
—Oh, cut it out.
—It is no good the honourable member opposite complaining about this Government. Road safety was a very poor priority under his Government.
—He was on the Committee with me and attended the meetings.
—Order! The honourable member for Franklin will cease interjecting.
—Don't start on the Road Safety Committee.
—Order!
—He attended the meetings.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Franklin.
—I don't care.
—I name the honourable member for Franklin.
—Mr Speaker, I suggest that the honourable member will cool down and offer his apologies to the Chair. Perhaps we can wait until he cools down and offers his apologies.

—I take the point made by the Leader of the House, but I do not think members should feel free to defy the Chair when a request has been made of them. Under the circumstances I will not persist with the request for his suspension. I ask honourable members to pay the Chair courtesy and respect and not to answer back when a request has been made.

—There has been a 31 per cent increase in expenditure for road safety and promotion and research under this Budget and that evidences the importance we attach to improving road safety. But even though a substantial reduction was made in the level of road casualties last year, there is no room for complacency and this Government has no intention of relaxing its efforts to increase road safety and to reduce the level of road casualties and injuries.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I ask whether he can inform honourable members of the impact of the Federal Budget on Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Science and Technology. How do the Minister and the Government to which he belongs reconcile the increase in money terms of only 1.6 per cent, representing a disastrous real cut in spending on science and technology, to pick up a word from the Australian Academy of Science in the context of this big spending Budget with its overall increase in outlays of 13 per cent-there is plenty of money for everything else- with his constant insistence on science and technology as a major driving force in sustainable economic growth and new jobs, as science and technology surely are? Alternatively, is it true that he threatened or is about to resign? The Minister evidently gets trampled on when the big unions crack the whip at this Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Berowra on his question, I think the first he has asked this year as the Opposition spokesman on science and technology. That is an interesting indication of the very high priority the Opposition gives these matters. I thought the question that he asked might in fact be harder. I think it is easy to reconcile. First, we need to recognise that between last year and this year there has been an enormous change in the political climate so far as the funding of science and technology is concerned. Last year, my Department was Robinson Crusoe in this area. This year that is no longer the case. Since last year, the States have become seriously involved in the funding of science and technology. Western Australia, Queensland and Victoria, particularly, are putting many millions of dollars into it and are carrying out programs that to a large extent parallel those that have been developed by the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, even the much vaunted private sector has now come out of the closet to some extent. It is now starting to put investment into research and development, even in the small business area. It was not doing so before. The banks are much more liberal and flexible in the area than they were. We also have to take into account the amount of Commonwealth revenue forgone in the management and investment companies scheme. That also does not get added to the Budget outlay for science and technology, but it has to be taken into account. In addition, the very significant increase in expenditure in education, particularly in the university sector, has very serious implications for research work.

In addition, there are three other major areas for which funds were not required in this year's Budget. These are Landsat which is transferred to the Department of Resources and Energy, Interscan which has now finished the research and development phase and the construction of the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory. I would not pretend that this was an overwhelmingly expansionary Budget in science and technology--

TALK.START.PARA: —But things will get better.
—The Prime Minister assures me, and I would not want Hansard to miss it, that things will get better. That is absolutely correct but it has to be recognised that the Budget--
—Is the CSIRO happy?

—Of course it is not happy. The Academy of Science is not happy either and I would not say that I was particularly happy, but I recognise that we live in a political reality. By the end of the year we will have had seven elections in 12 years and it was obvious that there were a number of priority areas which we all agreed to in the overall Budget strategy. There had to be a recognition of the need for tax relief, especially for people on lower income levels. There was a recognition of a need to provide greater social justice for the people at the bottom of the socio-economic pyramid. There was a need to keep the prices and income accord on foot, and also to provide funding in areas where it was possible to do immediate good.

ANSWER.PARA: The difficulty that I face in my portfolio is that we are dealing with a longer timeframe. In a Budget we are dealing with matters that can be dealt with within a 12-month period. I am concerned about the things for which we make plans for 10, 15 or 20 years ahead, to the year 2000 and beyond. In a democratic society it is inevitable, especially in an election year, that the immediate demands will always win out over long term ones. However in the long term we will all be disadvantaged unless we undertake that long term planning. I believe that that aspect of our Budget processes is seriously defective and I hope it will be redressed in 1985.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Health advise whether any decision has been taken on the possible transfer of nurse education from hospital based courses to courses in colleges of advanced education.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to be able to tell the honourable member for Canning that a decision has been made by the Government and I take the opportunity to commend her for the very constructive and creative role she has played in negotiations for the development of this program. The Government is committed in principle to the transfer of nurse education from hospital programs to colleges of advanced education. Subject to satisfactory transition and cost sharing arrangements with the States, the last intake into hospital based courses will be in 1990, meaning that the phasing out will be completed by 1993.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government believes that this decision will bring benefits to the health care area. First of all, it will provide a better educated and more flexibly trained nursing profession. Secondly, it will create greater employment opportunities for fully trained nurses. Thirdly, it will bring occupational and vocational benefits, particularly to women. Fourthly, it will certainly help to underwrite the status of nursing as a major profession in the health care field.

The timing to which the Government has committed itself is designed to ensure that the transfer of nurse education from hospitals to colleges will take place in a planned and orderly way gradually over the phased period. If this were not so there could be problems with the replacement of trainees taken out of the hospitals by trained nurses and there could be an over-stretching of resources in our tertiary sector. So recognising the need for this, the Government has determined to play a role in its planning to ensure an orderly and proper transfer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Using the Government's own Budget estimates of the non-farm product deflator and growth in average weekly earnings in 1984-85, is it a fact that an Australian taxpayer on average weekly earnings with a dependent spouse and two children will actually have less real disposable income in 1984-85 than in 1983-84, despite receiving the so-called tax cuts and working more overtime?

—The answer is no. The fact is that a taxpayer will be better off. I indicated yesterday that 2 1/2 million taxpayers will have a lower marginal rate of tax as a result of these progressive tax changes in the system than the Deputy Leader of the Opposition suggests. I wish to make this point because there seems to be a misunderstanding by both the Leader and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. They have tried to put the view about that the only rate that matters is the marginal rate. In fact, every taxpayer in Australia will have the benefit firstly of the tax free threshold of $4,595, then the new tax rate of 25 per cent which cuts in at $4,595 and runs to $12,500. The 30 per cent rate comes in at $12,500--
—Disposable income has nothing to do with that.
—The honourable Leader of the National Party will cease his interjections.

—While the 46 per cent rate remains, the fact is that there is a lower marginal rate of tax and more taxpayers will receive a cut in their tax. This is a real tax cut and the taxpayer's disposable income will rise as a result. Because of some convoluted logic and arithmetic, the Leader of the Opposition is trying to suggest that disposable income will in fact decline when there is a very real tax cut of $2.1 billion in a full year and $1.3 billion in 1984-85.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health, who represents the Minister for Social Security in this House. It relates to the strike by computer operators in the United Kingdom Department of Health and Social Security which is now entering its fourth month. Is the Minister aware of the continuing distress which is being caused to United Kingdom pensioners, many of whom are located in my electorate of Kingston, by the disruption to United Kingdom pension payments resulting from that computer operators strike? Can he outline to the House the measures that have been taken to alleviate the situation of those United Kingdom pensioners, particularly those who rely on that pension for a substantial part of their income? Can he particularly reassure the House that the recent change in the notional rate of exchange which applies to United Kingdom pensions will not disadvantage many of those pensioners who are not receiving the cheques to which the new rate of exchange applies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the difficulties caused by industrial trouble in the British Department of Health and Social Security. I have noted that the honourable member for Kingston has been assiduous at all levels in trying to solve the very real difficulties that have occurred for British pensioners. Since May there has been a strike of computer workers in the British Department of Health and Social Security and this has affected, or has the potential to affect, some 85,000 United Kingdom pensioners in Australia. While those pensioners are no longer getting computer cheques, they should be by now getting their cheques on a manual basis through a system of emergency relief. Let me explain to honourable members because this might be useful for the advice they can give. The British Government has put in place three mechanisms to deal with this problem. First of all, the pensioners concerned can write direct to the British Department of Health and Social Security and ask in return mail for emergency relief which will continue until the strike is settled. Secondly, they can go to British consulates-general which will telex the British Department of Health and Social Security and get an immediate payment of emergency relief, by return mail, which will again continue until the strike is settled.

ANSWER.PARA: Thirdly, they can go to consuls and there are provisions for immediate relief to be paid for out of funds in Australia. We are aware of the difficulties. The Department of Social Security is closely monitoring the problem and it is maintaining liaison with the British authorities in this country to make sure that particular personal difficulties are resolved.

In relation to the other point raised by the honourable member for Kingston, the system of a notional exchange rate is the most effective method for dealing with computer cheques but I should make it clear to all honourable members that if any pensioner finds that there is a difference between the actual exchange rate and the notional exchange rate, he can get a manual assessment.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In making this statement the Government is continuing its practice of announcing the legislation program at the start of each period of sittings to provide a basis for informed and open public debate about major national issues. There would be no stronger indication than that already given by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that during the current sittings the Government will be building on its proud record of sound economic management and progressive social reform which was established by last year's Budget and consolidated during the autumn sittings this year. This Government has had to tackle during its 17 months in government economic and social problems of a kind not seen in this country for over 50 years. Our program should be seen in this light.

SPEECH.PARA: Our major objective this sittings will be to provide sufficient fiscal stimulus to maintain the momentum of private sector expansion, including by direct support for business; to provide further improvements in pensions and other welfare payments; and to provide tax cuts which will support the accord, boost family income and stimulate consumer spending-all this while achieving a significant reduction in the Budget deficit.

In addition to the key Budget Bills already introduced on Budget night, we intend introducing further Bills to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act, the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act and the Bank Account Debits Tax Administration Act to implement measures announced in or before the Budget. We intend to continue our fight against tax avoidance with Bills to counter trust stripping schemes. In addition to revising the Medicare levy threshold and ceiling we will introduce a Bill to amend the National Health Act and the Health Insurance Act which will, among other things: Alter drug pricing arrangements and encourage provision of respite care in nursing homes.

We will introduce a Bill to implement a new Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement which will launch a 10-year assault on housing related poverty. In addition to a further social security and repatriation legislation amendment Bill we intend if time permits to introduce a supported accommodation assistance program to provide support for those in crisis situations and for the chronically homeless. The home and community care part of the aged care package is to be introduced in the autumn sittings next year. We intend to amend the Trade Practices Act by repealing sections 45D and 45E and will be amending the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to provide a mechanism whereby secondary boycott disputes can be dealt with by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. We also intend to introduce a Bill to bring about a major consolidation of all existing veterans' entitlement legislation. The Government will be embarking on major industry restructuring and assistance measures, all of which have already been announced and some extensively canvassed. Briefly, these will include legislation to:

Establish an automotive industry authority as part of the revised assistance to the industry. Associated with this initiative will be the introduction of measures to provide support for the design and development of motor vehicles;
Revise industry arrangements for the retail marketing of petrol;

Amend the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act to facilitate and encourage off-shore petroleum exploration and development activity, and to give effect to the area to be avoided by ships around the Bass Strait petroleum production facilities;
Introduce a package of Bills to restructure the wheat marketing and pricing arrangements;
Revise arrangements for the fishing industry to introduce a new management policy and further assistance measures;
Amend the export inspection charge provisions for meat, dairy products and eggs following review of these procedures; and
Revise arrangements for the canned fruits marketing industry.

The Government also intends to introduce, if time permits, a package of Bills to reorganise the dairy marketing industry. These will not be passed during the Budget sittings but will provide the opportunity for detailed public debate to take place on a more informed basis.

As already announced by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan), the Government will introduce a major item of legislation to revise the system of grants to the States and the Northern Territory for schools assistance . This will be introduced together with States grants bills for tertiary education, as well as Bills to adjust grants levels in line with cost supplementation arrangements. In line with an announcement made last April the Government intends introducing a Bill to amend various electoral, health, social security and education Acts to bring arrangements for Christmas Island broadly into line with those for the rest of Australia. Bills will also be introduced to :
Enhance the role, jurisdiction and enforcement powers of the Human Rights Commission;
Introduce changes to the supplementary licence scheme for broadcasting and television in preparation for its early commencement;
Guarantee borrowings raised by Qantas to purchase Boeing 767 aircraft;
Enhance the Commonwealth's ability to collect air navigation charges and introduce separate airport charges;
Enable the Empress of Australia to be replaced, thereby ensuring the survival of the Bass Strait sea passenger service;
Replenish Australia's contribution to the International Development Fund;
Restrict the use of Australian passports to Australian citizens and remove the distinction between immigrants who are British subjects and those who are not; and
Implement the report of the Remuneration Tribunal in respect of salaries and allowances following the 1984 general review.

In addition, the usual Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill will include a number of matters of minor significance. We will, of course, be proceeding with Bills before the Parliament, including:
The Constitution alteration Bills;
Defence and repatriation Bills;
Conciliation and arbitration; and
The six export inspection charge Bills.

As always, unforeseen circumstances may give rise to additional legislation, and pressure on parliamentary debating time as well as on the Parliamentary Counsel's time and resources may not enable all of the legislation forecast to come forward as soon as we would like. In addition, the Government may still consider other measures which could result in legislation in the current sittings. However, the program I have outlined continues the direction of reform established by the Government thus far.
I commend the Government's program and look forward to the assistance of honourable members from both sides of the House for its implementation.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Opposition endorses the concept of a statement of this order which gives some idea of the intended legislative program. However, a number of aspects of this particular program need commenting on. The first relates to the comments today by the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones), who indicated yet again to us that this is an election year and we can expect anything and perhaps all things from this Government for the purpose of trying to achieve electoral success without really knowing whether or not it will achieve it. The Leader of the House (Mr Young) in his introductory comments showed further indication that that is his intent. His peroration referred to economic and social problems of a kind not seen in this country for over 50 years. The economic problems, of course, were significantly better because of the actions of the previous Government. The breaking of the drought, beyond all other factors, contributed very much to the improvement in economic conditions. This rather contrasts the beneficial aspects of the economy with almost every other period during the last 50 years. So one does not look at that peroration in anything other than a somewhat critical manner.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly there are social problems. One of the saddening parts of this program is that there is little in mind that is going to overcome the difficulties for private employers in trying to regenerate employment opportunities so that the business community can again make profits and employ people. Sadly, nothing in this program is going to improve that position. The program contains some very interesting contrasts. One of the omissions concerns the means test. One can only be appalled that it is not in the statement; it may be in the very vague phrase on page 2, where the Minister refers to a further social security and repatriation legislation amendment Bill. There is no indication of an intention to introduce into the House a package of means test proposals that will finally lay to rest the total uncertainty of everyone in the community about social welfare benefits. I would have thought that that would have been one of the very first measures introduced in this Budget session. Unless this legislation is covered in that embracing phrase I am afraid that every pensioner in Australia will be left in a continuing state of uncertainty about whether or not his pension will be ripped from him, whether the government pension policeman is going to knock on his door, or whether there will be yet another category of means tested items which will deny the pension to yet another group of pensioners. Frankly, it is totally unacceptable to exclude that from this Budget program.

The intention to amend the Trade Practices Act by repealing section 45D and section 45E is another proposal that we on this side of the House deplore. There is little doubt that there are many abuses of the industrial system by the big and powerful trade unions. Only in the last few weeks there have been attempts to blackball a number of fuel wholesalers throughout New South Wales on the basis that they require employees to join the trade union movement before they receive future supplies of fuel. There are other indications in other parts of Australia that those same malpractices are taking place. Any proposal to weaken in any way the necessary legislation to protect the rights of employers, disadvantaged consumers and, of course, individual trade unionists is absolutely unacceptable to this side of the House.

I note that there are a number of interventionary pieces of legislation in mind in respect of the industry packages. The Opposition parties will be looking at those very closely when they come before us. I note that in one area affecting primary industry there is to be amending legislation with respect to the export inspection charge. I dare to suggest that there will be no change in those very onerous increases affecting meat exports that have already been introduced by Labor in government. Every meat exporter in this country is in a state of total uncertainty about the future because of the rate and measure of the increased charge. I suggest that those measures, when introduced into this Parliament, will need to provide some reduction if there is to be any price competitiveness, and that, again, I rather doubt.

I notice from page 4 of the statement that we are to see another bit of electoral rigging to try to ensure that the present honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Reeves) is able to resist the onslaught from the very distinguished Chief Minister of the Northern Territory by including Christmas Island in the division of the Northern Territory for electoral purposes. What an incredible set-up this is. There are a good many island territories around Australia. Yet legislation is to be rushed precipitately into the House to enable Christmas Island to be included in the electoral division of the Northern Territory at the next election because the Australian Labor Party thinks it has a few votes there. I wonder why it does not do the same with Norfolk Island or perhaps Heard and Macquarie Islands? There are any number of other islands one can think of. But, oh no, Christmas Island happens to have a few potential Labor voters. I hate to disillusion honourable members opposite, but I rather suspect that by the time the people up there have met Paul Everingham they will realise that in him they have a jolly sight more effective champion than any Labor candidate would be. I think the results of the election, as the honourable member for the Northern Territory already knows, are already well and truly understood by everybody who knows the electoral realities in that part of the world.

Finally, I notice with some pleasure that legislation is to be introduced to provide supplementary licences for broadcasting and television. This is an advance which we in the coalition parties welcome. It is something that follows initiatives taken some little while ago, when I was Minister for Communications. I welcome the fact that this legislation is to be introduced. There are, of course, many other pieces of legislation in this program. We will all be interested to see how long and how often the House sits in order that the legislation can be passed. Having heard from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that he is about to announce the election date, and having had that confirmed today by the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones), we can all expect that there will be a precipitate rush to the polls. The disarray that is emerging day by day within the Australian Labor Party suggests that that short term electoral popularity which at least the pollsters suggest the Government enjoys will not last for very long at all. I rather suggest that the consequences of its Budget and of this program will add significantly to the Government's disadvantage whenever the election is held.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In his report on the financial statements of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust for the years ended 30 June 1981, 1982 and 1983 the Auditor-General expressed strong criticisms of its operations. As a result of these reports I took a number of actions. I granted leave of absence to Mr R. Hammond, the Chairman of the Trust, whose actions had in particular attracted the attention of the Auditor-General. I established an enquiry conducted by Mr John Monaghan, a Commissioner of the Public Service Board and now Auditor-General designate, whose report was presented to me on 30 March 1984. This report has been tabled in the Parliament. A working party which included representatives of the trade unions has considered a range of matters and an enquiry has been completed into the possible need for disciplinary action. Both those reports have been made available to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, which has under reference matters relating to the Trust.

SPEECH.PARA: When all the evidence is in, when all the reports have been considered, when I am confident that all views have been fully taken account of and mature judgment has been exercised, I will bring before this House a comprehensive plan to secure the future well-being of the moneys in the care of the Trust. For the moment I can inform the House that the Trust has assured me that the Trust's operations are proceeding normally, its investments continue to be profitable, and there is no substance to reports that its funds are at risk. Meanwhile, Mr Hammond has offered to resign as Chairman and I have indicated my agreement with that course of action. I have made it clear that I do not hold him guilty of any improper or reckless conduct in the conduct of the investment program of the Trust. On the contrary, I accept the conclusion of Mr Monaghan, which stated:

. . . neither the (decision-making) processes as such, nor their application in the specific investment projects examined by the inquiry, indicate recklessness or incompetence in making investment decisions.
I am reinforced in this conclusion by the written submission of the current Trust to the Senate Finance and Government Operations Committee. The Trust states unequivocally:
. . . the current Trust agrees that there is nothing dishonest on a large scale . It also wishes to make clear that, equally, there is no evidence of dishonesty on a small scale.
The Trust also points to this conclusion of Nobel Lowndes Australia:

in the period from 1 July 1976 to 30 June 1983, the Trust's performance in the property, shares and short term investment sectors, was superior to the notional performance of two of the largest life office funds . . .

In that sense, Mr Hammond has done the job he was appointed to do. The much quoted low earning rate of the Fund is due entirely to the huge losses suffered through the investments made before the Trust was established. Some specific allegations about Mr Hammond's actions have been made in evidence to the Senate Finance and Government Operations Committee by the former Chief Investment Manager of the Trust. The most damaging allegations related to the acceptance of gifts by Mr Hammond. I will table at the end of this statement a document prepared by my Department demonstrating that Mr Hammond in all cases followed the correct procedures.

On the two other specific allegations, one relating to the minutes of Jen Pty Ltd, and the other to a letter sent to the Imperial Services Club, I am advised by both my Department and the current Trust that, although the wisdom of these actions may be questioned, no harm has been done and no further action is necessary or contemplated. Both Mr Brigden and Mr Monaghan have pointed to weaknesses in the internal administration of the Trust. There were undoubtedly mitigating circumstances arising from matters. such as staff ceilings, which were outside the control of the Trust.

The final allocation of responsibility for these weaknesses is still to be resolved. In the meantime, Mr Hammond has acknowledged weaknesses in the system and in a spirit of co-operation has asked to be relieved of the Chairman's responsibilities so that the management structure of the Trust can be strengthened and upon the basis that it will enable him to devote more of this time to the supervision of some important projects. The current Trust has proposed that from the date of his resignation as Chairman Mr Hammond should be temporarily employed in a consultancy capacity to ensure continuity, in particular, in the management of the very large Grosvenor Place project. Mr Hammond's rights will be fully protected as if he had served his full term as Chairman of the Trust. I have indicated that I am quite happy with this arrangement as an effective way of utilising Mr Hammond's skills. As I indicated I would do earlier, I now table the document relating to gifts.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The statement which has just been made by the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) is the second statement regarding the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust. I point to two matters relating to the operations of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust: Firstly, administration and, secondly, investment. In the area of administration, it is quite clear that the trust has not had a good record over a period of years. I hope that the working party to which the Minister referred will come to some conclusions on administration. An enormous amount of money is involved in this area. There is no doubt that the question of administration will have to be addressed in order to ensure that participants are satisfied that their money is being well cared for. These days the administration of superannuation trusts is complex and costly. Certainly, a vast improvement can be effected in that area by the effective use of computers and management techniques.

SPEECH.PARA: The second area of concern is that of investment. The propositions which came forward in the Minister's previous statement about certain investments which took place would raise the interest of any person, either an investor or a person interested in the financial world. I was disturbed by some of the matters which were referred to by the Minister on that occasion. I note that the inquiry found there was no dishonesty. I think that finding has to be accepted but there is no doubt at all that an effort was made to make certain tax advantages that would, in my view, rightly fall to the Trust available to those outside the Trust. I go further down the trail on that issue. I have always held the view that investment knowledge is not to be found in Canberra. It is time that investment trusts in the superannuation area were put out to tender. This would allow the very considerable improvement in investment techniques and management that has occurred in Australia in the last 10 years to be effected on these superannuation funds. I understand that Mr Hammond, the former Chairman, went to the job with a reputation as a good investor and broker.
