DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Speaker has received a letter from the member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The damage to Australia/United States relations caused by Government policy and statements of the Foreign Minister.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The actions of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) over the last 15 or 16 months of the Government's period in office regarding foreign affairs have been characterised by a succession of efforts to put out fires created by unsound and unthinking statements by his Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden). Sometimes the fire fighting can be done from the confines of Canberra using the modern paraphernalia of communications, such as the telephone, the cables and the media. But sometimes, as occurred with the Association of South East Asian Nations when the leaders of those countries could take no more gratuitous insults, the Prime Minister has had to jet in, smooth those ruffled feathers and try to restore our national pride and reputation by a succession of statements designed to smooth those troubled waters. This month has been an extraordinary month in Australian foreign policy. Anybody who has had any doubts about the capacity of the Foreign Minister to fly off at a tangent and light these fires will only have to recall events in this House yesterday when he precipitated this House into an immigration debate which this side of the House did not want nor seek. Mr Hayden's performance received an X rating, quite properly, in the newspapers this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: This week has seen another product, and a dangerous product, of the Foreign Minister's playing with fire. Honourable members will have seen the press grapple with the fact that the governing party of the United States, at its convention this week, dropped specific references to Australia and New Zealand in its listing of friends in this region. The Government has had plenty of time to pull this situation around and we welcome the State Department announcement implying that the Republican Party was not the Republican Administration. Confirmation that ANZUS remained central to United States policy was valuable and helpful. But we must ask why Australia has come under unfavourable notice in high political circles in the United States. The reaction to New Zealand is understandable. But why Australia? Is the Republican Party important? Of course it is important. We know that the statement of the Republican Party is not binding on the Administration. But the fact remains that the Republican Party is the governing party, and looks likely to remain the governing party in the foreseeable future in the United States. The fact that it has taken this action should cause everyone in Australia very great concern.

History repeated itself earlier this month, on 8 August. Banner headlines in the leading Australian dailies proclaimed that the Foreign Minister, in Geneva attending disarmament negotiations, announced that he was prepared to shut down United States facilities in Australia if the United States did not perform better in disarmament negotiations. The Melbourne Age, mentioned with approbation by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the House today, reported the following remarks by the Foreign Minister:

'If we were to discover that these facilities were in fact part of a link in a first-strike capacity we would be morally required to review the way these facilities function and our commitment to them.

'Similarly, if we were to discover that in spite of our commitment concerning these facilities there was in important quarters a lack of general commitment and determination towards the comprehensive test ban treaty, then we would have to review in some important respects the outline of our thinking in respect of these matters.

The Press interpreted these remarks-and any reasonable man would say correctly interpreted these remarks-to be directed at the United States and motivated by a desire of the Foreign Minister to respond to pressures within the Labor Party. The Prime Minister dismissed the remarks as hypothetical; but the gravamen of the situation is that the remarks remain on the public record. That is why the matter is of such importance and so serious. They have not been retracted by the Foreign Minister and therefore constitute a threat to the stability of Australia -United States relations. Indeed, party functionaries, such as Mr Schacht in Adelaide, a Centre Left colleague of the Foreign Minister, have been busy setting the scene within the Labor Party to rally to the cause being promoted by the Foreign Minister. Journalists, who pride themselves on being close to the counsels of the Labor Party, predicted in print that a struggle would ensue, and an effort would be made to build the Foreign Minister's threat into national Labor Party policy. We would like to think that the Foreign Minister has come to the conclusion that he has misjudged public opinion on this matter and is now prepared to resile from his foolish course. Nothing, however, has been said by him which reassures in any way this side of the House. Nor does the Prime Minister seem to be at all happy, having in mind the fact that the Foreign Minister has the numbers in Caucus in a matter such as this.

The Australian people still have a genuine cause for concern about the direction of Foreign policy. We should keep in mind that the Foreign Minister, for the first time in Australia's history, enjoys a higher standing in the capitals of Vietnam and the totalitarian states of the world than with our traditional allies.

There is something more important to any nation than its national security. The Australian people, faced with international uncertainties created by a growing Soviet presence in South East Asia and the western Pacific, are clearly of the view that our security is more effectively maintained by a close working relationship with the United States, for it is the United States alone that has the capability to offset growing Soviet strength. It is the United States which shares the values which undergird our way of life. It is the United States which has maintained stability in the western Pacific, and it is under the mantle of security that Japan and other nations, including ourselves, have built up successful economies.

It is no light matter in an international forum on disarmament to impugn our ally and leave unstated the genuine problems which face our region. The Prime Minister unfortunately, against, I would hope, his better retrospective judgment , is in the middle of a mess of his own making. He has been pressuring the United States since he came into office to agree to a nuclear free zone in the Pacific. There were no hazards in this proposal, he argued. Why, the whole thing is a thoroughly painless idea with the particular value of appeasing the left wing in the Labor Party. The Prime Minister has been tempted to think he will be able to tell Australia that he has achieved a nuclear free zone in the Pacific. With that emblem of success, the Left will have to listen to his voice.

But the catch is that the Prime Minister's nuclear free zone is not the one that David Lange wants. Prime Minister Lange is supported by Michael Somare and Walter Lini, and Walter Lini is supported by his Cuban embassy, Helen Caldicott, Bill Hartley, and a whole host of nuclear free collectives that have appended their aspirations to the Labor Party. It all came together in Port Moresby. Mr Lange was being stubborn and the little piece of public relations-a nuclear free zone in the south-west Pacific-was becoming an embarrassment. The Government was in the midst of toil's to invent an escape hatch. The Age gave some account of the basic approach on Friday last. I read from the report of the Age:

Australia has made major concessions to the New Zealand Labor Government and to other Pacific Governments opposed to nuclear vessels in the Pacific in a draft proposal for a nuclear-free Pacific to be discussed by the South Pacific forum.

The Australian proposal, being circulated by the forum's secretariat prior to meeting in Tuvalu on 27 and 28 August, recognises the rights of any member to ban ships or aircraft of another nation from its ports or airfields.
The Australian proposal is likely to displease the United States, now engaged in negotiations with New Zealand over the Lange Government's policy banning nuclear vessels from its ports.

The Australian draft sits uncomfortably with warnings from the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the Foreign Minister, Mr Hayden, about the consequences for New Zealand of implementing the ban on nuclear vessels.

It appears to represent a compromise proposal between the Government's stand that a nuclear-free Pacific should not prevent the transit of the area by nuclear-powered or nuclear-armed vessels and the position of the New Zealand Government banning vessels from its ports. The New Zealand position has been supported by Papua New Guinea.

The Australian proposal is that Forum countries 'reaffirm their sovereign rights to decide for themselves, consistent with . . . their security arrangements, and such questions as the access to their ports and airfields by vessels and aircraft of other countries.'

The new proposal toughens draft recommendations for declaring the Pacific a nuclear-free zone which the Australian Government presented to the last South Pacific Forum in Canberra last August. Those recommendations were strongly criticised in the forum's closed session by the Prime Ministers of Vanuatu and Western Samoa as being too accommodating of the U.S. desire to maintain unfettered transit rights of the Pacific for its nuclear-armed and nuclear- powered vessels.

The 1983 forum deferred consideration of the nuclear-free zone proposal until this year, while officials tried to reconcile the differences between the tougher line favoured by some of the South Pacific Island States and the Australian Government's view of its responsibilities as a member of Anzus.

On Tuesday last, in a front page report, the Age drew attention to United States concerns about the increasing Soviet military presence in South East Asia and the Pacific. It reported that officials of the Pacific command said that between 20 and 25 Soviet naval ships and submarines now operate from Vietnam and long range patrol planes and medium bombers range over South-East Asia. The Age reported that the American command was particularly concerned at the way support facilities were building up. In an editorial on the same day, the Age noted:

It is not necessary to be an alarmist to understand that Washington's ability to establish and maintain a deterrent to expanding Soviet designs in the Pacific basin could be compromised by the precedent set in New Zealand last month. Whether we in the South Pacific like it or not, the issue in question is one of such fundamental and overriding importance to the defence policies of the Western powers that nothing anyone may say in the forum will change attitudes in Washington or Paris. Perhaps the key to understanding . . . such an apparently compromised position is to know that in effect it changes nothing. Recognising the right of a country to ban visits by nuclear power ships does not necessarily imply approval of such action. Australia, then, wants to have it both ways.

As the Age editorial demonstrates, the Government is tinkering with matters of fundamental and overriding importance. The reason why the issue is fundamental should be clear to the Government. For years, Australia, like other Pacific countries, has prospered in a region where Soviet influence has been at a minimum. Soviet interests have escalated in the Middle East and the Horn of Africa. This influence has bought warfare and suffering. In Afghanistan, a whole nation is being destroyed and three million refugees have been added to the world's refugee population. In the Pacific the United States has used its power to restrain the Soviet Union in north-east Asia and this has provided Japan with the security needed for its economic miracle.

What we have now, is a Government which has incapacitated itself to give leadership to the Pacific countries in its standing international requirement to assess and balance in a sensible way considerations of national and international security, involving as they do the creation of a security system which creates stability and diminishes potential for conflict, and a security system which relies decreasingly on weapons of mass destruction. It is important to shift an emphasis on to arms control negotiation, but in the process it is reckless to the Pacific to downgrade the benefits of the world-wide system of security sponsored by the United States.

The Pacific basin is one of the fastest growing regions in the world. Critics of the United States such as the Foreign Minister, so quick to point out where the United States may go wrong, fail to bring before people of the Pacific the fact that the security system we have, has made a fundamental contribution to the stability of the region. It has left the region truly, apart from Vietnam's depredations in Kampuchea, one of a zone of peace, which has served the prosperity of us all.

Australians will have to think hard about the future. The Soviet Union has greatly strengthened its influence, militarily in north-east Asia, and politically in South East Asia. There seems to be an unchallenged view that the dialogue between the Soviet and the United States has deteriorated to such an extent that the risk of nuclear war has sharply increased. I do not believe for a moment that that is true. As evidence of that, only a week or so ago the Soviet Ambassador to the United States signed an agreement to upgrade the hot- line between Moscow and Washington.

There are some signs that a younger generation of Soviet leaders will come to recognise that the foolish ideological commitments of Stalin have not produced a serviceable society in Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, let alone one which should be exported under the threat of international conflict. We do have a duty to maintain a system of counsel and consultation with the United States. If the Foreign Minister has any concerns he should surely address them to the Prime Minister, so that he can sensibly bring them into a sensible framework for discussion with the United States President. If he takes himself out of the picture a bit, puts Australia, and this means his own leadership, more effectively into the centre of the action, he would be doing himself and this nation a service. Clearly these issues are of a gravity and importance that would justify a more co-ordinated approach by the Government. They are certainly not the issues which can be served by big-noting and the factional competition which is now a characteristic of this Government.

This Government has tried its level best to condition Australian public opinion and the media to accept its bitter divisions as one of the foibles of the national political scene. But what we have in our foreign policy-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say this: The United States-Australian leg of the ANZUS alliance is in very good shape and we have a strong sharing of common values. I say that with stress. It is in direct conflict with what the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) has just put to the House. Let me say it again, through the Chair, directly to the honourable member for Warringah. The United States-Australian leg of the alliance is in very good shape and we have a strong sharing of common values. I ask the honourable member what he has to say about that. It conflicts with what he has said.
—Why threaten it by gratuitous insults? That is what I have to say.

—The range of alleged gratuitous insults which the honourable member raised today cover a fairly extended period. The comment which I made at the beginning of my speech was made by Secretary of State Shultz in Canberra on 15 July after he had spoken with me and discussed the United States-Australian relationship.

SPEECH.PARA: The House ought to be clear about the tactic adopted by the honourable member for Warringah. This is the umpteeth time he has either raised in Parliament or declared in some concocted Press statement that the Australian-American alliance is in disarray because of some imagined slight on the part of Australia towards the United States. The first thing I want to say is this: It is clear what the intent of the honourable member is. It is simply to try to undermine the very strong foundation of confidence which successive governments have established between Australia and the United States in their formal alliance and through the spirit of their association which is merely reflected by that formal alliance, but valuably reflected. That is what the honourable member is about. He is incapable of producing any concrete evidence to substantiate his wild and feverish assertions. The fascinating thing is that the only comments which are made suggesting that the alliance is in a state of seige or extreme stress come from the honourable member and his colleagues. The only public comments being made by the United States Administration, and they are innumerable, attest to the strength of the relationship. In June 1983 President Reagan said:
Australia is a great nation that plays a vital role in regional and world affairs. It's a key ally upon whom we can count.
Secretary of State Shultz on 18 July, in a speech at Honolulu after the ANZUS Council meeting in Wellington which he and I, and the New Zealand representative attended said:

In the South Pacific, the focus of our policy is our Anzus allies, Australia and New Zealand. These are countries that share with us proud traditions of democratic freedom and a willingness to bear the cost of preserving those values .

The focus of the United States policy is its ANZUS allies in the South Pacific which share with the United States proud traditions. The honourable member for Warringah wants to undermine and destroy the confidence and mutual respect which has been built up in the relationship. It is a shame that he does not keep up with his reading and pay attention to what is presented in the media. He released a Press statement-he took the precaution of not dating it, but I believe it was the night before last-in which he said:
Today's press report that Australia and New Zealand have been removed--
I stress that word 'removed'-
from the Republican Party list of countries in our region enjoying a special relationship with the United States is significant.
It reflects a growing concern in United States political circles about the anti -US trend--

The honourable member goes on to blame me. As the honourable member sought to catch up a little today it is more than a mere matter of trying to repair the nonsensical comment he made to say that that is in the Republican Party platform and acknowledge that it is not binding on the Administration. He tried then to concoct some justification for his silly statement. Let me tell him what we have on the cable traffic from Washington. We have an extract from a Press statement released by the State Department on the 23rd instant. It states:

We wish to make clear, as we have done repeatedly, that the United States Government attaches the highest importance to Anzus and to our excellent relationship with the Government of Australia, including the personal relationship between President Reagan and Prime Minister Hawke.

Let me go further. The honourable member asserts that there is still some dark significance about the fact that Australia has been dropped from the Republican Party platform which is, after all, the Party of the Administration. Let me tell him what other information we have. In 1980 the Republican platform referred to the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation as the cornerstone of United States Defense policy. That is also omitted from the 1984 platform. We went down the drain with NATO. What feverish hysteria is manufactured by the honourable member for Warringah on occasions like this. What sort of service is he trying to do this country by seeking to undermine the confidence of our allies in the relationship which his Party in Government cemented as much as earlier Labor governments and as much as this Government is seeking to do?

I think it is about time in the parliamentary forum that there was an effort to establish some bipartisanship on the key areas of foreign policy. I find as I travel around perplexity at the way in which the Government works hard to try to establish, develop and elaborate the productiveness of associations with various countries whose association with us is important. Then the Opposition seeks to undermine it. It cannot understand. There is a lack of patriotic commitment to the best interests of the nation. The honourable member sought to manufacture some sort of problem in the Association of South-East Asian nations region as a result of initiatives I have taken, very largely after consultation with and, in important respects, at the direction of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Let me tell the honourable member what is being said in the ASEAN countries as recently as 4 August. The Nation Review of Bangkok, reporting on a speech I made to the Foreign Correspondence Club, said this about me in its editorial:
His analysis was clear and cogent and we do not have anything to subtract from it or add to it.

It concluded, in respect of the declaration which I made in detail about the purposes of our policy concerning Indo-China, that our proposals-perhaps they may be productive at some stage, perhaps not but we are in there trying-are positive about getting parties together and talking. It stated:
He-
Hayden-

is perfectly right. ASEAN leaders will be thankful to Australia if it could get Vietnam to the conference table. In an over-simplified form, what Hayden says is , ''Give Vietnam a chance.'' What we say is, ''Give peace a chance.''

That is the end of it. That is what we are about, trying to give peace a chance in the region. But the honourable member is determined to misrepresent, to misconstrue and to try to put the darkest and most destructive constructions that he can on what this Government is about. I repeat: Is it not about time that there was a little single-minded national purpose behind the main motives that go into our foreign policy and that they were presented as a united force in this country? Our foreign policy projects itself beyond the shores of this nation to the other countries of this region and to other parts of the world. If we cannot talk with one voice on important issues we will not be taken seriously elsewhere. People will be wondering what sort of parliamentary system we have.

The most extraordinary thing I find about this is that when one pares away all of the brouhaha and the posturing which is veneered over the core of what the Opposition has to say, the essential principles between us are the same. I will mention one or two quotes from a speech of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) on 6 June 1984. Quite candidly, I believe it was a speech which was deserving of much more commendatory attention than it attracted on that occasion . It was thoughtful-politics were put to one side-and on the key points I endorse what was said. For instance, in relation to ANZUS the Leader of the Opposition said this:

It has been said so often . . . that the Treaty does not guarantee that any party will do anything other than consult. That is the only actual guarantee within it. Nor is Australia committed under ANZUS to support any sort of American policy. What happens in any situation will therefore depend on a whole range of factors.

There is nothing exceptional about that, except this: That is the point we were establishing last year when we participated with the United States in our review of the ANZUS alliance. We established it and the United States endorsed it, and the honourable member for Warringah condemned it. So we can make the system work with our allies but we cannot satisfy the honourable member for Warringah. All I can say is that he ought to listen a bit more closely on foreign policy, on principles, to what his leader has to say.

Having said that I will move on, as the honourable member wishes, to my recent visit to Geneva. When I was in Geneva I made some points. I said essentially that deterrence and disarmament are complementary concepts, but that was said before I said it today. It was said by the Leader of the Opposition in his speech on 6 June 1984, and I think better said in many respects, because of its succinctness, than I said it. But that is essentially what I was saying and what I said in the rather vigorous debate which took place in this country in the lead up to Labor's national conference. There can be no doubting the commitment I have to the alliance and the patriotic discharge I displayed for this country and the alliance in that debate. So why try to blacken a clear commitment, a commitment of integrity, on those matters?

I will paraphrase what the Leader of the Opposition said in his speech. He said that we need to continue to press for a comprehensive test ban treaty, a review of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and prohibition of all weapons for use in outer space. Then he said this:
I wish time permitted us, even after this lengthy period, to go further through the importance of using our pressure in this area.

I repeat: 'Our pressure in this area'. That is a very self-respecting, commendable and proper expression of view. He was saying that we are not some outlying dependent province in this alliance, that this is not a treaty of guarantee between a senior partner and a junior partner in which the senior partner makes all the commitment and the junior partner has no obligations. This is a treaty of mutual commitment between partners sharing equal respect for one another. In that regard, if we have a view, because of our involvement in the strategic nuclear deployment in the world, we have a right to be heard. Deterrence and disarmament are complementary. It was in that context that I made some comments in Geneva. I said that if a first strike capability were to be developed in respect of the facilities we would be required 'to review the way in which those facilities function and our commitment to them'. That is on the record. It is, exactly as the Prime Minister said, a hypothetical proposition. It is something that may happen. Like nuclear war, it may happen. When nuclear war ceases to be hypothetical, when it is present tense, it will be a terminal case and we will not be worrying much about it. That is why we address some of these things in a hypothetical way in certain circumstances. But let me also say that this should be read down in conjunction with what I said in the booklet which I table in July entitled 'Uranium, The Joint Facilities, Disarmament and Peace'. At page 81 I point out:
The submarine-launched ballistic missiles on American vessels are not sufficiently accurate to be used for the purpose of a pre-emptive first strike . . .

But even if the missiles did get a counter-force capability, a hard target capability, the Soviets also have a deployment of nuclear ballistic bearing submarines which act as a deterrent. So we are not talking sensibly in the near future, as far ahead as I can see, of a first strike capability being established. I also said that if there were no progress in respect of the matter of a comprehensive test ban treaty we would be concerned and we may want to review policy. But the fact is there has been progress. The Americans endorsed what we put forward. In a cable I received from Geneva this is what the Americans said:

With regard to the United States delegation, the United States Ambassador ( Fields) has told me that he thought Mr Hayden's statement was a very significant one. . . . He said that Mr Hayden's statement was refreshingly direct and demonstrated the ''up-front'' approach of Western countries . . .
The Deputy Director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, David Emery, . . . reiterated what he said on 7 August--
to our representatives there-
namely that he thought the approach towards a comprehensive test ban and its verification put by Mr Hayden in his statement to the Committee on Disarmament was acceptable to the United States.

But it is not acceptable to the Opposition. Frankly, I am not worried whether it is acceptable to the honourable member for Warringah or not. We are establishing our case where it counts. We are establishing our credentials for self-respect, independent judgment and a positive assertion of what we believe to be in the best interests of this country and the world, and we will continue to do it without apologies.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill gives effect to a resolution of the Hobart meeting of the Australian Constitutional Convention in 1976. The proposal was also embodied in a resolution of the Adelaide convention in 1983 on four-year terms. It has strong cross-party support from the Convention. When the Bill was last before the Parliament it was supported by the Opposition. The same proposal was in fact put forward by the Fraser Government in 1977 and was part of an election proposal put forward by the Fraser Government in February 1983.

The Bill ensures that henceforth Senate elections will always be held in conjunction with House of Representatives elections. It does this by making senators' terms equal to two terms of the House of Representatives and by expressly providing that Senate and House elections will be held on the same day . The terms of existing senators are converted to terms equal to two terms of the House of Representatives in the case of long term senators and one term of the House in the case of short term senators. The cost savings by avoiding the possibility of separate half-Senate elections in future are staggering. On current costs a separate half-Senate election costs the taxpayer an extra $17.8m . Although Senate and House elections will be brought into place by an election for the House before June 1985, History shows that they are unlikely to remain in phase. When regard is had to the pattern of elections in the last 20 years this becomes obvious. In that time there have been 11 elections, only two of them being combined-three House, three half-Senate and three double dissolutions . If they were to remain out of phase no fewer than seven separate elections would be due in the next 10 years-three for the House of Representatives and four for half the Senate. Further details on the Bill are set out in the second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) of 13 June 1984. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Spender) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill gives effect to resolutions of the Australian Constitutional Convention passed at every session of the Convention from 1973 to 1983. One of the few significant achievements at the Adelaide Convention in April last year was that unanimity was reached on the details of the proposal. Now, unfortunately, the Opposition has changed its view but, nevertheless, the Government believes that it should put this important proposal to the people in conjunction with proposals for simultaneous elections, or 'terms of senators', as it is now formally called.

The Bill does two things. It clarifies the basis upon which references of power may be made from the States to the Commonwealth. Such references may, of course, be made under section 51 (37) of the Constitution, and some have been made from time to time, not least from Queensland and Tasmania. It also, for the first time, enables the Commonwealth to refer its exclusive powers to the States. References either way will be able to be made subject to conditions or for a limited term and will be able to be revoked. The Bill will not itself affect the balance of power between the Commonwealth and the States. What it will do will be to introduce a much needed element of flexibility into the Constitution by setting up a framework within which Commonwealth-State negotiation over the transfer of powers may take place.

The Bill was supported by the Opposition when last before the Parliament but is now opposed. No justification of principle for this opposition to the Bill has been given and it appears indefensible. The proposal has been strongly supported in the past by State Premiers from both sides of politics, with the exception of the Queensland Premier. It should continue to be supported by those who wish to see a better distribution of legislative powers worked out by agreement between the Commonwealth and the States. Further details concerning the Bill are explained in the second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) of 13 June 1984. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROPOSED JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON VIDEO CLASSIFICATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —Special Minister of State) (3.55)-by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a Joint Select Committee be appointed to report on the operation of Regulation 4A of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations and the A.C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 in relation to videotapes and videodiscs and in particular-

(a) the effectiveness of such legislation by comparison with previous legislation purporting to govern the importation, production, reproduction, sale and hire of violent, pornographic or otherwise obscene material;
(b) whether the present classification system, as applied by the Film Censorship Board, is adequate as a basis for import and point of sale controls;
(c) whether video retailers are observing the conditions of sale or hire attached to 'X' classified material, particularly in relation to children under 18 years;

(d) whether Regulation 4A of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations is adequate in identifying categories of prohibited material, and operating effectively in preventing the importation of videotapes/discs falling within the prohibited categories;
(e) whether children under the age of 18 years are gaining access to videotapes /discs containing violent, pornographic or otherwise obscene material;

(f) whether the A.C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 should be amended to make it an offence for persons purchasing or hiring 'X' classified videotapes/discs to allow, suffer or negligently permit children to view such material;
(g) whether cinemas should be permitted to screen for public exhibition 'X' classified material, subject to prohibition from entry of persons under the age of 18 years;

(h) whether films which would merit an 'X' classification are being produced in Australia and if so whether Australian men and women are adequately protected by existing law from pressure to act in such films, and
(i) the likely effects upon people, especially children, of exposure to violent , pornographic or otherwise obscene material.

(2) That the committee consist of 7 members, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House or the Government Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition or the Opposition Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Leader of the National Party, the Deputy Leader of the National Party or the National Party Whip, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.
(3) That every nomination of a member of the Committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(4) That the Committee proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(5) That the Committee elect a Government Member as its Chairman.

(6) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.

(8) That the quorum of the Committee be 3 members.
(9) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources.

(10) That the Committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations it may deem fit.

The Government recognised, at the end of the last sitting of Parliament, a genuine concern on all sides of the House, and in the country, about censorship arrangements as they related to privately owned video cassette recorders. At that time, we indicated our sympathy with the proposal that a joint committee should examine the social dangers of videotapes and cassettes which depict a variety of perverse behaviour becoming widely available, and perhaps accessible to children.

Over the recess the question has been carefully considered by the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans). He examined the present position in Australia and studied legislative responses to the same problems in Britain and Europe. As a result of these deliberations, we have identified a number of areas which could be valuably scrutinised by a joint committee, with the object of recommending legislative action should existing provisions for the protection of children and safeguards against the exploitation of women-and for that matter, men-appear inadequate.

It is important to recognise, at the threshold of this inquiry, that we are dealing with deep questions of psychology, sociology and communal values. They cannot be answered by cheap political point scoring, or by over-hasty and slap- dash research. There is a philosophical dimension as well: The state must hold in a fine balance the right of its citizens to view what they wish, and the duty of Government to protect the most vulnerable members of society from harmful materials.

We will look to the Joint Committee either for reassurance that we have the balance just about right, or else for guidance as to how the balance can be readjusted by legislative amendment. In weighing this difficult problem, we are anxious to avoid undue delay: That is why we have set terms of reference which focus on specific concerns. We are mindful of the fact that the United States of America's Presidential Commission on Obscentity and Pornography, and the United Kingdom's Williams Committee on the same subject, both took upwards of three years to deliver their findings on broad general issues. I do not think any honourable member would want us to wait that length of time. by focusing on specific targets, we hope that the Joint Committee will be able to reach useful conclusions within a time frame consistent with careful deliberation and receipt of both scientific research and properly argued submissions from various community groups.

Let me give a brief overview of the problem, and explain how the terms of reference will enable the Joint Committee to tackle it. When the Government brought forward its censorship package at the end of last year, we were particularly concerned to end the vagueness and uncertainty which had bedevilled the subject previously. We also sought to establish for the first time effective point of sale controls which would prevent pornographic material being sold to minors and stop it from being merchandised in ways which would give offence to reasonable citizens.

These goals have, we believe, substantially been achieved in relation to books, magazines and films. It is in relation to video cassettes that doubts have set in, on a number of fronts. The video cassette seemed to offer a means by which consenting adults could watch, in the privacy of their own home, material of a kind which would do them no harm, but of which the majority of people would disapprove.

A special category-class X-was established for videos of this sort. There is another category of material, objectionable because it could harm adults by encouraging paedophilia, bestiality, sadistic violence, acts of terrorism or drug abuse, which is entirely prohibited. Now the wisdom of creating a class X has been challenged, on the ground that it can in practice become accessible to children, either because reckless or dishonest traders are prepared to breach the law by selling or hiring to minors, or because irresponsible or neglectful adults may allow children to view it.

The Government shares this concern, and is most anxious for the Joint Committee to assess it and to recommend reforms if any are needed. Our main motive in establishing the Joint Committee is to ensure that there are adequate safeguards to protect children; but in making that judgment we invite the Committee to report on other matters which our own consultations suggest may also require attention. These further concerns are:
(a) Previous Legislation

This part of the terms of reference invites a comparison between the new arrangements and the old. The Mahoney report of the Review of Customs Administration and Procedures called for legislative reform to guide customs officers in relation to the importation of different classes of pornography: Have the definitions in the new legislation been capable of reasonable application? The Government was also concerned to produce a system which would end the involvement of organised crime in pornography trafficking. We believe that this has been substantially achieved, but would welcome the Joint Committee 's confirmation.
